title: gps-87-mile-run-save-lives-premiered-borders
story: THE inspiring story of a doctor who marked his retirement by tackling an -mile run across Scotlandrsquos stunning countryside has been made in to a new film.And it is being premiered in the Borders this week.Former GP Alan Matthews took on the four-day fitness challenge from Inverness to Skye with his sons Gregor and Cameron in the summer of  for Cancer Research UK and the Scottish Association for Mental Health.The challenge, which raised pound, for the charities, was developed into Run Across Scotland - a -minute film made by Rich Watson of Flux Video.The film highlights the highs and lows of the challenge which started at the Kessock Bridge near Inverness and took on the iconic Great Glen Way by Loch Ness and remote Glen Affric before heading past Eilean Donan Castle and finishing over the Skye Bridge.Now the film is being premiered at the Peebles Outdoor Film Festival on Friday at the Eastgate Theatre, Peebles at pm.Dr Matthews, , told us: ldquoIrsquom looking forward to seeing the film on the big screen for the first time as itrsquos packed full of special memories.ldquoWersquore so lucky to live in Scotland and I hope this film will inspire others to make the most of the outdoors."After  years as a doctor Irsquod seen the many real challenges faced by patients and families affected by cancer and mental health illness.ldquoThe facts are striking."One in two born after  in the UK will be diagnosed with some form of cancer in their letime and one in four people in the UK will experience a mental health problem."The Run Across Scotland challenge was only for four days but many people with cancer or mental illness face challenges every day of their lives. We wanted to acknowledge that and do something that could help.Run Across Scotland will be screened on Friday as part of the The Sea Around Me - a series of short films that celebrate wild places on our doorstep.And they will be followed by a talk by ing and natural history broadcaster Miranda Krestovnikoff.Tickets for the event, which cost pound, are available from the Eastgate box office.

title: want-lead-st-ronans
story: ST RONANrsquoS Border Games Committee is inviting nominations for the positions of Standard Bearer and Principal Guest for .Both will play leading roles in townrsquos annual celebrations at Games Week , which runs from July  to .Chairman Alan Patterson said: ldquoWe are now seeking nominations for candidates to lead the rd Anniversary of the Games.ldquoWe have been running the public nomination process for the last few years and we hope that the public will help the selection committees once again by nominating deserving people for these important positions."Standard Bearer - The Standard Bearer of Innerleithen is introduced on May  and installed during Games Week. The Standard Bearer carries the Blue Banner of St Ronanrsquos, plays a leading role throughout Games Week and is the representative of the Burgh, travelling to neighbouring towns as they celebrate their own festivals during the summer months. The Standard Bearer goes on to be right and left hand supporter and retires from the flag party three years after the original own year in office. The Standard Bearer is expected to take an active part in the work of the Games Committee during his term of office and beyond.Principal Guest - The Principal Guest is invited to give the main address during the Cleikum Ceremonies on July  and presents St Ronan and the Dux Girl with their medals. The Principal Guest is involved in other events throughout Games Week. The Principal Guest is often someone who has been associated in some way with the town through their activities or interests or who has shown a commitment to the le and work of the community. Equally, they may have less current links with the area, but through some association, have an interest in the affairs of Innerleithen or St Ronanrsquos Games. Principal Guest is a one year, honorary appointment.Nominations are open now for both positions and will close on February  - after which no nominations will be considered. Nominations should be made in writing to Joint Secretary, K J Belleville, Braeside, Wells Brae, Innerleithen, EH JE or by email to KJBelleville@outlookNominations must include the full name and address of the person being nominated, the post that they are being nominated foralong with an explanation for the reason for the nomination. The nomination must be signed and have the full name and address of the proposer.

title: author-margarets-jolly-good-fellow
story: A BORDERS award-winning novelist has been appointed as the Creative Writing Fellow with Tyne and Esk Writers.Margaret Skea already has five novels and a book of short stories to her credit.The St Andrews graduate from Kelso is well-placed to mentor and encourage the eight local groups of aspiring writers in East Lothian and Midlothian, as well as critiquing their work during the winter months.Margaret, who has also studied creative writing, is a recent chair of the Borders Writing Group..She told us: "I see my role as a mentor to enable members of the groups to improve and develop their writing skills whether they are writing for pleasure of aiming for publication."The groups comprise members who are writing at all stages of development."During her initial meetings with the groups Margaret included mini workshops while also providing an opportunity for constructive critiquing of members new work.Margaretrsquos own books are historical fiction and based on conflict.She explained: "I grew up in Ulster at the height of the Troubles, so it was perhaps inevitable that I would one day write about living with conflict."Her first award-winning book Turn of the Tide is based in Scotland and features two warring clans.

title: tank-building-begins-border-households-prepare-water-upgrade
story: WORK is about to begin on a major new water tank to supply households across the central Borders.As part of the pound million upgrade of services, Scottish Water engineers will start constructing the large clear tank - which can hold five Olympic swimming pools worth of water - next to the A outside Selkirk.The utility firm has already laid two thirds of the new pipes required for the upgrade along a seven-mile route between Selkirk and Galashiels.The work will deliver improved treatment processes, environmental benefits and a more resilient supply to , homes and businesses in areas including Selkirk, Galashiels, Melrose, Lauder, Fountainhall and Newton St Boswells.Customers in these areas are now being notied of the introduction of a new water treatment process called chloramination as part of the upgrade.Chlorine has been traditionally used for many years to keep drinking water safe.But the chloramination process lasts longer in the pipe distribution system and lowers the levels of chlorine in water coming out of the tap.Scott Fraser, communities manager at Scottish Water, said: ldquoWe are starting the chloramination process in the Borders to ensure our customers continue to receive a reliable supply of high quality drinking water."Chloramination is a tried and tested way of delivering this which and is already used in the supply to more than a quarter of our customers across Scotland."Customers in Selkirk, Melrose, Lauder and some of Galashiels, served by Howden Water Treatment Works will have their supply changed over towards the end of February.Customers in other areas ndash including the West of Galashiels and Fountainhall ndash will start getting water treated with the new process later in the year.Scottish Water has written to affected customers letting them know that the change was due to take place.A further part of the pound million upgrade is the installation of new filters at the Howden Treatment Works, which will force up to  million litres a day through . micrometre wide straws -  times narrower than the thickness of cling film.Manse Street Water Treatment Works, to the west of Galashiels, will be also switched off next year and converted into service reservoir to help to improve flows in the Caddon Water during dry summer periods.

title: get-yer-bikes-regions-newest-music-festival
story: A NEW festival will take place this summer on the shores of St Marys Loch.But many of the revellers face a scenic day in the saddle before they can dance the night away.The Muck n Mac Festival is the brainchild of former Galashiels Academy pupil Cameron Balsour.Tickets for the July get-together dont just include an evening of music, entertainment and fine food in the Yarrow Valley but also organised cycle runs to and from Galashiels.Cameron explained: "St Marys Loch is a stunning location and well have a full evening of music in the big marquee as well as other entertainment and workshops."For the cyclists taking part they will have the choice of a fully marked road- or off-road route to reach the festival site, as well as a dferent route to come back the following day."The whole weekend will be a great mix of riding bikes and music."A range of tickets are available for the Muck n Mac Festival, from a full weekend package which includes a Friday evening soiree at the Tempest Brewery, Saturday and Sunday cycles, and the main Saturday evening event at St Marys Loch, through to passes for inidual rides and other parts of the weekend..Cameron added: "We are making the Muck n Mac accessible to as many people as we can."There is a free tent and baggage drop off to and from the festival village, theres loch-side camping, charging points for E-bikes and lots of family-friendly activities."People can choose to ride on one day or two - ortheyd rather just attend the music side of things they can do that as well."The Borders is a beautul place and theres nowhere better to have a festival like this."The Muck n Mack Festival will be hend on the weekend of July  to .For further details and tickets visit www.mucknmacfest

title: cold-comfort-safe-school-evacuation
story: CONCERNS have been expressed over the evacuation of students from Peebles High School following the blaze that ripped through the school last year.Peebles community councillor John Crawley, said it was ldquoout of the fire and into the freezer for the  pupils who were safely brought out of the burning building at the end of November.Mr Crawley quizzed the Councilrsquos Chief Executive Tracey Logan, regarding the provision for pupils in the aftermath of the emergency evacuation.At a meeting of Peebles Community Council last Thursday evening, he said: ldquoWhen the kids were decanted they wound up in a large open space on an extremely cold day in ious states of dress because some of them had to leave from the gym hall.ldquoWith that in mind, there was absolutely no provision outside the school to accommodate kids in that situation."As far as Irsquom aware there were no emergency blankets to keep kids warm. Will you take that on board and have you learned any lessons about the mass evacuation of a school in extreme weather, whereby yoursquore actually putting kids at risk of dferent kind of injury when they got decanted out But the council chief said she did not agree that children were at risk.ldquoI think we always learn lessons from these kinds of events. We took action really quickly and the Fire Service were very happy with how the children were evacuated. We put in place very quick arrangements with the help of the community in taking a large amount of children to Priorsford School and down here . We did give out blankets and we did have facilities. Lots of members of community and older children who had extra coats were handing them out.It was acknowledged that the evacuated students could have sought refuge in the Sports Complex.ldquoThe one bit of learning that we do have is there was some consideration as to whether children could go into the Sports Complex, they could have, but they didnrsquot, said Ms Logan.ldquoThat would have been a safe place for them to go because itrsquos a separate building that wasnrsquot at risk of any fire. There will always be learning but genuinely I donrsquot think any children were at risk.Mr Crawley believes more provisions should be put in place for emergencies.He added: ldquoA small building remote from the school in the evacuation area that was pre-stocked with a supply of those things to cater for the head count in the school wouldrsquove avoided having to rely on the good nature of neighbours and halls so they could go immediately and start handing them out in the inclement weather.However, Ms Logan said the number of emergency incidents like this were very few adding: ldquoWe have to be careful we donrsquot over prepare for things, yoursquove got to have appropriate measures."I donrsquot think Irsquom aware of a single child that was cold to the point that it was a problem. We do have emergency blankets. I do think the provisions were adequate but we can always look to seetherersquos  we can do.

title: leader january 17 2020
story: Inspirational five-year-old Esmie MacLean who is fundraising to help her brother access expensive autism treatment can teach us all a lesson on altruism.While many children her age would be dreaming of what they want for their birthday # Esmie is six on Sunday # she has signed herself up to run m at this year#s MOK Run, which is no small feat for someone with such little legs.They say that early intervention can be the key to success, and other parents who have tried out the therapies for which Esmie is raising money, speak of outstanding results.It can be very hard to #go public# with such personal family matters, so not only should Esmie be commended, but also her mum and dad, Iona and Scott, who had the courage to talk out for the benefit of their family.Campbeltown always rallies when it comes to such worthwhile causes and every penny counts, so please donate whatever you can.We would like to wish Esmie the very best of luck for the race # and, of course, a very happy birthday on Sunday.

title: former-depute-lord-lieutenant-receives-telegram-queen-diamond-wedding
story: Marlene, , and Stan, , married in  and have four children together ndash now aged between  and . They also have five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, one of whom is just a few weeks old.The Port Seton couple had a surprise celebration with their loved ones at the Waterside Bistro in Haddington on Boxing Day and were joined by the Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian Michael Williams and deputy Lynn Marshall, who greeted Marlene with a huge bunch of flowers and her very own telegram from Her Majesty The Queen.Marlene told the Courier: ldquoIt was very exciting. I knew that at some point I would have got a telegram but with our anniversary being on Boxing Day, I didnrsquot know when it would be.Marlene, who has always been heavily involved in the community, said she was ldquopassionate about where she lives.She got involved with the villagersquos gala committee when her children were young and went on to serve Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council for  years.She has also been the chair of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom for  years and was the chair of the community centre advisory committee before there was even a Port Seton Centre.She is still on the management committee for the centre and said she never thought she would live to see the new sports hall that she has passionately campaigned for, which is due to be finished by August.Marlene met her husband Stan, who was living in Leith at the time, ldquoquite by accident, she said.ldquoStanrsquos friendrsquos mother had a hut at the [Seton Sands] caravan site and the boys used to come down at the weekends [from Edinburgh], she said.ldquoI was going down to buy cigarettes for my friend and Stan shouted something out of the window of a car at me, and afterwards we realised we worked quite close to each other.ldquoI worked at the McEwanrsquos brewery [in Fountainbridge] as a telephonist and Stan worked for the North British Rubber Company at the time.ldquoWe used to meet at lunchtime and then Stan got into the habit of coming to Port Seton every weekend. He would just happen to be at the bus station when I finished work with no bus fare.The couple, of Inglis Avenue, married a year later, when Marlene was  and Stan was .Stan worked at Cockenzie Power Station for  years and even helped with the construction of the site before it opened in .He joked: ldquoI helped build it and helped tear it down!Marlene said of their marriage: ldquoWe never thought we would have made it to this milestone. I remember my father saying: lsquoI will give you six months.rsquoldquoWe had a lot of hard times, we were young and foolish and hard up, but for some unknown reason we managed to take the kids on holiday every year and buy them their season tickets for the swimming pool. We had to save all year for them.ldquoFor the young, I would say not to marry young. Irsquom very proud that none of my children have followed in our footsteps.ldquoI would say [in marriage] it is important to always be mindful of one another and try to be toleranthellip never keep an argument going. It is too easy nowadays to walk away but you just have to keep going. I wanted to kill him some days and it was probably likewise but we have had a great le together.ldquoWe feel very lucky to have reached this age and that all of our children have got good lives, and their children are just a delight to have around.In their retirement, Marlene and Stan have travelled most of the Mediterranean and much of Europe together, and enjoy looking after their grandchildren, who all live in the county.

Emma had been due on December  and had been in labour for two days before the couples son was born in the first minutes of .Grandparents Kevin and Denise Cunningham, of Port Seton, and Audrey and Dennis, were thrilled at the new addition.

title: new-mcbrave-games-event-held-musselburgh
story: The action-packed event, called McBrave Games, promises participants a uniquely Scottish experience with events such as tug orsquo war, tossing the caber, putting the shot, the hill race, weechinrsquo the welly and a Highland fling.There will also be a Scottish twist on challenges along the km obstacle course to test participants.The event takes place on Saturday, May , at Newhailes House.Participants can take on the challenge as a solo entrant or enter as a clan of four with colleagues or friends to battle it out to become the laddie or lassie of McBrave Games.Co-founders Jo Dytch and Andrew Hastings are confident the creativity and innovation behind the event will encourage entrants to try something new in .Jo and Andrew bring with them more than  yearsrsquo combined experience in the mass participation space on large-scale events such as Race for Le, Tough Mudder and the -mile Cateran Yomp.Commenting on the inspiration behind the event, Jo said: ldquoScotland is an inspiring and magical place. Bringing the Highland Games to everyone and making it accessible seems only right. ldquoAndrew added: ldquoThe idea of combining an epic obstacle race with the Highland Games really got us excited.ldquoIt has taken us the best part of a year to get the event from a concept ready to go.ldquoWe are both big believers in innovation and the McBrave Games is a new idea that takes the familiar and gives it a unique twist.Participants can register online.

title: double-yellow-lines-planned-haddingtons-long-stay-car-park
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed it will bring forward plans to crack down on bad parking at the free site near to Tesco in Haddington town centre.The move follows a controversial bid by the local authority to introduce a new alternative car park outside the town centre.A bid for a ldquotransportation hub to the east of the town was put forward last month and sparked an angry reaction from town centre traders, who fear it will put people off shopping in the centre.The council has launched a public consultation on Haddington town centre parking and transportation and this included an exhibition which showed images of people parking outwithallocated spaces in the current -space long-stay car park which is linked to Tescorsquos own short-stay customer car park.Under the heading ldquoindiscriminate parking, the images showed cars and vans parked on kerb corners and other unmarked areas of the car park which were not designated bays.It was, the council said, a way to illustrate the need for additional car parking in Haddington.Now the council has confirmed it is planning to introduce new traffic regulations which will stop people from parking outside spaces in the packed car park.A spokesperson said: ldquoA report will be presented to our cabinet meeting in January with proposals to introduce double yellow lines to the long-stay car park.This is to improve safety and reduce damage to the kerbs and road surfaces caused by indiscriminate parking.ldquoFollowing cabinet, the proposals will be subject to a statutory process before the necessary regulations could be introduced.Last October, the council introduced similar restrictions in its own staff car park at John Muir House, Haddington, which lies a short distance from the long-stay facility.That saw dozens of workers receive fines, from the team of private parking wardens employed by the council, for ignoring new yellow lines in their own car park.The long-stay car park in Haddington is on land owned by East Lothian Council and accessed through the adjoining short-stay car park attached to the neighbouring Tesco supermarket.

title: east-lothian-council-electric-bridge-closure
story: The Electric Bridge in Musselburgh was built to carry traffic involved in the construction of Cockenzie Power Station in the s and regularly opened on racedays in the town as traffic flooded in.However,ScottishPower announced last week that it would be closed from January , with no plans to re-open in the future.The company has been in discussions with East Lothian Council, which has already bought the majority of the former power station land, over the future ownership of the bridge.Those discussions seem to have hit the buffers after Musselburgh councillor Andrew Forrest told a meeting this week the future use of the bridge was ldquoout of everybodyrsquos hands.Reacting to calls from Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth for the council to take responsibility for the bridge, Mr Forrest told a meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeit was not down to them.He said: ldquoIt is their [ScottishPower]train set and they will play with it however they want to play with it.The Electric Bridge traditionally opened on race days at Musselburgh Racecourse to help with traffic through the busy town centre.When the power station closed in , the bridge, which spans the River Esk, was closed but an agreement was met with the racecourse, East Lothian Council and ScottishPower to open it for major events.At the MRAC meeting, racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said it was used until last year by the Musselburgh Riding of the Marches and was used by the Edinburgh Marathon as well as the racecourse.He described the decision by ScottishPower to close it as ldquodisappointing and said he had been told that ldquoScottishPower do not need it and East Lothian Council do not want it.Mr Farnsworth urged the local authority to try again to take ownership of the bridge, adding: ldquoWe are told the bridge is absolutely sound and in good order. It is a perfectlygood bridge that is being closed and we are urging councillors and the council to try and reach an agreement with ScottishPower.Howeve,r Mr Farnsworth was told that there was no reason why the racecourse itself could not approach ScottishPower to reach a separate agreement regarding opening the bridge in the future.

title: groundsman-almost-struck-replacing-divets-midway-race-musselburgh
story: The lsquonear-missrsquo incident occurredduring the Edinburgh Cup in September when groundstaff had been warned to remember the main race of the day would see the runners go round the course twice over the two-mile event.However, it appeared one of the workers forgot and was still replacing ets on the ground when the horses came round the bend towards him.It was only when he heard jockeys shouting at him to get out of the way that he managed to duck under the barriers to safety.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said a stewards inquiry was launched after the incident and the British Horseracing Authority investigated ruling that all protocolhad been followed by the racecourse itself.The incident came to light at a meeting of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee this week.Mr Farnsworth said: ldquoThe Edinburgh Cup is a two-mile race and our head groundsman warned all the groundstaff to remember they go round twice.ldquoOne of the groundsmen went out and obviously forgot it was a two-mile race.ldquoHe was busy knocking in the ets as horses came around the bend and jockeys had to shout at him.ldquoHe ducked off the track, it was a lsquonear missrsquo.He added that a similar incident at Ascot in November had seen that course fined nearly pound, by the British Horseracing Authority for not following the proper protocol before the race.Mr Farnsworth said: ldquoThe sport needs to decideit is safe for people to get on track during racing, it is weighing up the benefit of repairing the track with the risk. There is always a risk of human error.A spokesman for the British Horseracing Authority confirmed it had carried out an investigation into the incident during the Edinburgh Cup, adding: ldquoNo further action was required.

title: rugby-internationalist-recreates-st-marys-parish-church-gingerbread
story: St Maryrsquos Parish Church sits at the heart of Haddington and David Bergvall, with a little bit of help from partner Naomi Golightly and her five-year-old son Jackson Laing, has made his own, slightly smaller but definitely tastier, version!Naomi said: ldquoMy partner is from Sweden and he has been doing gingerbread house-making all his le.ldquoHe thought it would be an idea to make the church.ldquoIt was mostly him but me and my five-year-old son helped a little bit as well.The sweet version of the church measures a foot inand about six inches in height.David, who has represented Sweden in rugby union and plays for Haddington RFC, designed the walls and roof before taking it from the drawing board to the oven.The process took a couple of hours and Naomi, who works at Edinburgh Airport, said: ldquoWe have to roll everything out, cut each piece and put it in the oven.ldquoWe then need to wait for it to harden and stick it all together.ldquoThere were multiple trips back and forwards to the oven, which was my role.ldquoDavid cut templates out of cardboard and used that to cut round.ldquoIt was his mumrsquos recipe for the gingerbread house, so it is all homemade.Melted sugar was used to join the walls and roof together before it was decorated with a sprinkling of icing sugar to look like snow.The couplersquos creation attracted plenty of attention on social media, with David and Naomi making two versions of the edible structure.One has been given to Naomirsquos grandparents John and Val Golightly, who attend the church, with a second for her mum and dad Ruth Golightly and Colvin Denholm.David, who works for Alba Trees, has promised, though, that this is not the end of the gingerbread versions of the church.Instead, the -year-old from Umea,  kilometres to the north-east of Swedenrsquos capital city Stockholm, has vowed to make a ldquobigger and better version for next Christmas.Naomi, , said: ldquoDavid was drawing a picture for my grandparents for Christmas of the church, which is nice. As well as that, he decided to try to make the church.ldquoHe said this was just his first attempt and next year will be much better than this!

title: advice-bathing-continues-belhaven-bay-faecal-contamination
story: Scottish Water has advised that it is working around the clock to make Dunbar Waste Water Treatment Works fully operational after a substance spill from an external site into the network on December .It hopes to have the issue resolved by the end of January.Notices advising against bathing, paddling or playing in the sea or streams at Belhaven remain in place.

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-signs-top-rank-deal
story: The Prestonpans fighter, who last year became a double world champion at super lightweight, has signed a multi-year promotional agreement with Top Rank while also signing an advisory deal with MTK Global.He is set to make his debut on ESPN in the coming months.However, the move has drawn criticism from Cyclone Promotions, who Taylor signed with after turning professional.Taylor said: ldquoA new year, a new decade with lots of new beginnings and Irsquom starting this new decade with a big bang." was a huge year for me, but  looks set to be even bigger and Irsquom delighted to have signed a deal with Top Rank and ESPN and an advisory contract with MTK Global."I believe I am with the best team to take my career to the next level and I canrsquot wait to see what the future holds. I couldnt ask for a better partnership and know the future looks bright with this team lighting the way."Jamie Conlan, MTK Global professional development coordinator, added: ldquoJosh Taylor was  Fighter of the Year and won the Word Boxing Super Series in fantastic fashion with his win over Regis Prograis."Hes now linking up with Top Rank and MTK Global, so his sights are solely set on unying the ision and becoming a global star on both sides of the Atlantic.ldquoThis is a momentous partnership for all involved."MTK Global and Top Rank have a recent history of working together with world-class fighters and with Josh Taylor we believe that the best is yet to come, so  will be huge!Bob Arum, chairman of Top Rank, said: ldquoJosh Taylor is one of the worldrsquos best fighters and he is a fight fanrsquos fighter, a tough guy willing to fight anyone we put in front of him."Whether itrsquos Jose Ramirez in a fight for the undisputed junior welterweight title or any of the welterweights out there, hersquos ready for the biggest challenges.ldquoI want to thank Joshrsquos advisors at MTK Global, who have the same goal as us, which is to make him an international star.However, the announcement was met with disappointment by Cyclone Promotions.A statement from the organisation said: ldquoWe are very disappointed to read the news today that Josh Taylor has signed a promotional agreement with another promotional company.ldquoJosh Taylor is under an exclusive worldwide promotional contract with Cyclone Promotions.ldquoWe have successfully brought Josh to the pinnacle of the sport from the day he turned professional, including working alongside other stakeholders in boxing to deliver him the biggest fights.ldquoMost recently, Josh became IBF world champion in May , then unied champion in October , and we have been working since then to plan the next stage of his career.ldquoWe are saddened that Josh has felt the need to attempt to break his contract in this manner and frustrated at those who have caused him to do so.

title: dunbars-trial-20mph-speed-limit-set-become-permanent
story: The speed limit on the majority of streets to the north of the railway line was dropped from mph to mph in August .The change in speed limit was to be in place for  months before members of the public were given the chance to have their say on whether it should remain in place or revert back to the previous mph limit.A public consultation ndash both online and through leaflets posted through doors ndash was carried out to gather feedback.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire said the findings of the survey showed that the majority of people were in favour of keeping the reduced speed limit.He told Dunbar Community Council: ldquoThe survey results came back and  per cent of people were in support of it continuing.ldquoHowever, there were views that certain roads, distributor roads, as seen around the town should remain at  miles per hour.ldquoTransportation are reviewing the scheme and looking at roads they feel warrant ato mph. It will only be on major routes in the town but mph will continue because the survey results came back in favour of that.The final say on the scheme is likely to come at a council committee meeting, with a report currently being drawn up.Herbert Coutts, from the townrsquos community council, has been heavily involved in the move to see a reduced speed limit put in place.He said: ldquoI would be interested ndash presumably it is included within the report ndash to hear what the police evidence has been.ldquoThat is a big factor in all this.ldquoThe survey of public opinion is one thing but the police evidence and the results of the tests that were done in the same places where the council had recorded the speed of cars prior to the start of the trial [would be useful].A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the report would look at ious issues, including the public consultation and the possibility of including or removing streets from the mph speed limit. Similarly, it would highlight whether average speeds at ious hot spots had reduced.She added: ldquoIt was certainly noticeable on Summerfield Road that speed had reduced signicantly.

title: pubs-broken-port-seton-prestonpans
story: The Seaglass Inn on Links Road, Port Seton, and the Prestonpans Royal British Legion on Rope Walk were both targeted just before midnight on Sunday, January .Nothing was reported stolen from the Legion, while a two-figure sum of cash was taken from The Seaglass Inn.Police inquiries are ongoing to trace those responsible.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: "Officers in East Lothian are investigating after two premises were broken into on Sunday, January ."The incidents happened at addresses on Links Road just before midnight and Rope Walk at around .pm."Inquiries are ongoing and officers are working to establish any link between the incidents."Anyone with any information to help trace those responsible should call Police Scotland on  and quote incident number  of January or  of January  ."Alternatively, a report can be given to Crimestoppers anonymously on   ."

title: call-donate-old-christmas-cards-recycled
story: The initiative has been organised by local environmentally friendly and anti-litter group Love Musselburgh.Founder Melanie Roccio said: ldquoThe cards that are donated will be passed on to craft groups and others in Musselburgh and surrounding areas who can use them to make new cards or gt tags. There is no official cut-off date but Irsquom sure most people will be getting rid of their cards in the next week or so.ldquoThe Christmas card recycling project is hopefully a way to give non-recyclable cards a second use before going to landfill. Irsquom hoping this will also highlight the issue of waste generated over Christmas time.ldquoAround one billion cards end up in UK bins every year and so many of those are covered in glitter or foil, making them non-recyclable. Choosing cards, wrapping paper and gt tags made from recyclable materials will convert a huge amount of waste from landfill.Drop-off points have been set up at the townrsquos Mint Fig, Blueberry, Wilsonrsquos of Musselburgh, East Coast restaurant and Ravelston House Hotel.Melanie said: ldquoItrsquos great to have local, independent businesses supporting this project and Irsquom really grateful to all of them.Anyone who would like cards to reuse should contact Love Musselburgh via Facebook.The group, along with Cycle Connections, has also organised a Big Clean  in the town on January , am-pm. Litter picking and graffiti removal will be targeted. There is a limited supply of equipment, so participants are asked to take along their own gloves and litter picking sticksthey have them. Anyone interested in getting involved in the event should meet at the Old Town Hall.Melanie said: ldquoWe will focus on that end of High Street, Kerrrsquos Wynd and Newbigging.ldquoWersquoll also be engaging with the public to highlight the issues concerning them. All are welcome but, due to the busy location, it may not be suitable for very young children.

title: tims-tales-really-happened-dunglass-castle
story: ON THE edge of East Lothian, Dunglass Burn flows to the sea, having carved a dramatic ravine that forms the border between our county and Berwickshire.This natural wonder is often missed by those speeding along the main A, crossing over the modern bridge.I have written previously about the bridges here and the walk to the sea that takes you under them, and past the oldest one. This is a fascinating and picturesque structure from the th century, which lies semi-hidden amongst the trees that cling onto the steep sides of the slope.Dunglass is such a beautul area, and the ancient Dunglass Collegiate Church, dating from the th century, is one of its architectural jewels. Itrsquos open to the elements now, but well preserved and a popular place for weddings.The castle that once stood nearby is long gone. A more modern house sits on the spot where a mansion once stood, and before that the castle. Being on the main route south, the castle inevitably saw action during the ious times of war with England, being burned and damaged on a number of occasions in the s.But in August , the castle was effectively blown up in a huge explosion, and a version of events emerged which placed the blame on a vengeful servant called Edward Paris.It was a time of war and religious rage. Thomas the nd Earl of Haddington was leading a Covenanting force charged with defending this important route from the south, as the Covenanting army had entered England a few days earlier. He had established his force at Dunglass Castle, an obvious strategic location, to defend the armyrsquos rear.On that fateful day, August , , he was said to be in conversation with some fellow nobles when a huge explosion erupted from the vaults, instantly demolishing the central part of the castle which became little more than a pile of debris.Thomas and many others were killed, their bodies pulled from the rubble. They had been crushed by the collapse of the walls in the explosion.History has repeatedly recorded the names of the nobles killed on that day, but there were many others, as the castle was busy and full of people. Fty-four unnamed lsquocommon servantsrsquo were killed, and more than  other people badly injured, some later dying of their injuries.Edward Paris was Thomasrsquos servant and he has been blamed for this tragedy. The th-century writer Andrew Stevenson claimed Edward had the keys to the vault in which huge amounts of gunpowder had been stored, and he had been ldquoseduced by the enemies of the covenant to commit this act. He was an Englishman and another account says he was incensed at derogatory remarks made by Thomas about his countrymen.Irsquove always thought this explanation never really had the ring of truth. It was initially deemed an accident, and the story of Edwardrsquos role emerged later, instigated by a writer called William Lithgow, a man who had certain axes to grind. In one account, Edward is said to have thrust a hot poker into the gunpowder or set fire to it. The detail of this is suspect in itself, for who survived as a witness to this act  I suspect that a dreadful accident, possibly caused by incompetence and carelessness, was turned into a deliberate act of vengeance as it made a more useful explanation.Of course, it is very possible that Edward was offended or annoyed at things said by his master, and perhaps he mentioned this at some stage, later to be used as evidence of his guilt. But in truth, most servants will have seen or heard things which will have offended them, it was a part of their job.Imagineservants had been able to write and publish the things they had overheard and seen, what dferent historical narratives we would have!Motives for wanting to interpret the cause of the explosion in this way can be guessed at. It was a time of atrocity and massacre, with religious, political and national hatreds. Who was responsible for the dangerous stockpiling of the gunpowder in such a manner  It seems just too easy to blame a disgruntled servant. Even later, when writing up this period, religious and political loyalties influenced interpretation.If Edward Paris really did venture down to the vaults of Dunglass Castle on that fateful day, with the intention of committing suicide in order to kill his master, along with dozens of others, then he must have been infected with a deep hatred, as well as a total disregard for the lives of his fellow servants and his own.The truth is we will never know what really happened. But Edward Paris is a servant whose name we know. Countless numbers of so-called lsquocommon servantsrsquo whose lives and fates are deemed unimportant by history remain unrecorded just as the things they witnessed remain absent from our history books.Irsquove often thought it would be fascinating to meet Edwardrsquos ghost and ask him what really happened on that day.Silly idea, of course, but you never know.

title: public-exhibition-held-plans-revive-dunbars-east-beach
story: Dunbarrsquos East Beach, which hosts the townrsquos annual Loony Dook, was once a magnet for tourists but the disappearance of its golden sands over the years due to coastal erosion has led to fewer visitors.East Lothian Council has already been given permission for the first phase of work on the beach, which it is hoped will help sandwhile also protecting the shore.A public exhibition detailing plans for a second phase of work ndash and the project overall ndash takes place in Dunbarrsquos Bleachingfield Centre on Monday afternoon.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, explained the desire to see the beach restored to how it was previously.She said: ldquoIt has been a long-held ambition.ldquoPeople reminisce about how wonderful the beach was and there has been a lot of disappointment that it has been so rocky for so long.Dave Northcott, East Lothian Council structural engineer and project leader, visited the community council shortly before Christmas to outline the plans.Consent is already in place for the construction of a breakwater at the southern end of East Beach.Refurbishment of the existing groyne at the same end of the beach has also been approved, alongside the placement of rock armour at the toe of the seawall. A marine licence is in place until the end of May, with work to be complete before then.At the same time, plans are being drawn up for a second phase of work, which would see the creation of a breakwater at the northern end of the beach.A marine licence will be needed for that piece of work, with the hope that could be in place before the end of May to allow work to simply continue from the first phase.If that is not possible, the contractor will leave the site andat a later date to construct the northern breakwater.Mrs Swan, who is also chairwoman of Dunbar Shore and Harbour Neighbourhood Group, encouraged people to head along to the public exhibition, which takes place between pm and pm.Those in attendance can speak to the consultants and East Lothian Council about the plans.Mrs Swan added: ldquoI think it is really, really important for people to come to the exhibition for two reasons.ldquoOne is to understand the thinking that has gone into the regeneration project and the other one is to become aware of the impact it might have on them during the construction weeks because it is going to be at least six weeks and it could run into months.ldquoThe nature of the breakwater is they are built of huge rocks, between three and six tonnes, and they are all coming from the quarry at Markle. There will be heavy vehicles moving through the town over an extended period of time.

title: long-serving-haddington-gp-retires-42-years
story: Dr Ross Langlands has been a familiar face to people with all sorts of ailments in Haddington and surrounding villages for more than  years.On December , he was joined by colleagues at the townrsquos Lammermuir Medical Practice for a special lunch to mark his retirement.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite ambivalent.ldquoIt has been quite hard to say cheerio to folk that I have looked after for a long time.ldquoI have had lots of cards and presents as well.ldquoIt has really been quite nice but quite sad in some ways.Dr Langlands previously worked in Bangour Village Hospital, West Lothian, as well as in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and the Royal Northern Infirmary in Inverness, but it is Haddington that he has called home.He said there had been plenty of changes since he started working as a GP in East Lothian in the late s.ldquoA fair few people did not have as many telephones in those days, or as many cars, said Dr Langlands.ldquoThere were many more house calls then and I used to have a sort of rota where I would go out to Garvald on a Tuesday.ldquoSomebody would be waiting at the edge of the village to flag me down and tell me who I needed to see it was quite quaint.Dr Langlands, who has four children ndash Alasdair, Niall, Caitlin and Angus ndash was initially based on Haddingtonrsquos Church Street with one other doctor.The small building had two rooms ndash a waiting room-cum-secretaryrsquos room and a consultant room.That all changed in  when the medical centre was moved to Newton Port, with the building extended to cope with an increasing population.Now, the medical centre is home to more than a dozen doctors, as well as nursing staff, with Tyne, Lammermuir and Orchard practices all under one roof.Dr Langlands highlighted how medicine had changed over the decades ndash in years gone by he did home deliveries and ulcers were treated with surgery rather than medication.However, the -year-old is not planning to simply sit with his feet up at home in Haddington, alongside we Debbie Strachan, who is a GP at Whitesands Medical Practice in Dunbar.He said: ldquoI think I feel like I would like some time for myself while I am still reasonably fit and able to pursue my wider interests.ldquoI did an Open University degree about  years ago and have kept up to date with geology.ldquoI plan to go on field trips and I enjoy gardening and cycling.ldquoI signed up for a couple of short courses and will be studying Spanish, English literature and politics.ldquoI will not be wearying, I donrsquot think.ldquoAlso, my we has got a long list of things to do.Stephanie Currie, practice manager at Lammermuir Medical Practice, described Dr Langlandsrsquo last day as ldquoan emotional occasion and that he would be ldquogreatly missed, definitely. She said: ldquoHe had lots of gts from patients handed in over the desk and gts from staff and doctors at all the practices.

title: stone-well-artworks-set-wallyford-housing-development
story: The public artwork project for the St Clements Wells site, planned by East Lothian Developments, was outlined to members of the villagersquos community council at its recent AGM.Susheila Jamieson and James Gordon, of Rachan Design, have designed large, chunky stone wells or circles with deep relief patterns, measuring six feet in diameter.They will be positioned vertically at both entrances to the new housing development on the east and west sides of Wallyford.Establishing a theme for the artwork involved carrying out research into the area and talking to local resident, historian and community council chairman Alister Hadden.Mr Hadden, who was re-elected community council chairman at the AGM, said St Clements Wells farm on the south side of Wallyford, at the foot of Farsquoside Hill, played a very important role in the local community as farming preceded coal mining, which became the big industrial employer.He added that the area had one of the biggest distilleries in Scotland, which was started in  by the Mylne family.Liz Curtis of the Scottish Place-Name Society added: ldquoClement was a Christian in first-century Rome. He was said to have been martyred at sea with an anchor round his neck and was therefore regarded as the patron saint of sailors. The cult of Clement spread to Scandinavia in about the th century and then to Britain.ldquoSt Clements Wells were probably named by Scandinavians living in the Tranent area.ldquoWe know they were here because of the presence of a powerful landholder of likely Scandinavian descent, Thor of Tranent, son of Swain, who is mentioned in many th-century charters. He held extensive lands in the area and granted the church of Tranent to Holyrood Abbey.Mr Hadden said: ldquoI am sure the new stone sculptures will add another piece of culture to our area when in place to the east and west sides of Wallyford alongside those we have already.ldquoThese include the mining memorial stone and coal hutches located at St Clements Housing estate just off Salters Road, the  mining stones at the Wallyford Bing, a community woodland depicting dferent mining scenes, and also the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh memorial at the west side of Wallyford.The shapes and patterns proposed relate to the themes of the wells, water, ripples, distilling, agriculture and the sense of space and open skies of the site as it is now. The overall idea is that the artwork reflects past, present and future heritages of the area.There will also be two St Clements Wells name  per entrance in stone, either hand carved or sandblasted.The idea for a stone village sign for Wallyford is also being explored in a design reflecting the ideas of crossing a river or burn by a ford.A spokesman for East Lothian Developments said: ldquoEast Lothian Developments are delighted to be working with Susheila and James to deliver ious artworks at St Clements Wells.ldquoThey have shown real enthusiasm and creativity with the ideas they have brought forward to capture something of the history of St Clements Wells and design pieces which we hope will do justice to the entrances of the development, and spark interest from all those who will pass them.ldquoWe were very grateful to the community council for their comments and input to the designs.Elaine Di Troia was appointed vice-chairman at the AGM, Sharon Jamieson secretary and Beryl Stevenson treasurer. Ann Patton, a member for three years, is also continuing her work as a community councillor.

title: a1-closed-high-sided-vehicles-saturday-due-high-winds
story: The whole route through East Lothian from the A Old Craighall junction to the English Border was closed to all high-sided vehicles for safety reasons, the second time this week.The closure tookeffect from midnight and was lted at about .pm after the wind eased.Meanwhile, the road wasclosed to all vehicles between Haddington and Thistly Cross Roundabout due to the winds. That closure has also now been lted.The Met Office re-issued a yellow lsquobe awarersquo warning for strong winds on Wednesday following a previous high winds warning for Tuesday.This weekends weather warning began at am on Saturday and is in effect until pm.Previously, strong winds on Tuesday closed part of the A to all vehicles and the whole route to high-sided vehicles.However, two lorries were blown over in the gales.The decision taken to close the A to high-sided vehicles on both Tuesday and Saturday follows a number of lorries being blown over on the road in high winds last month - including one falling on top of a police car.

title: well-known-preston-lodge-school-nurse-viv-retires
story: Viv Donaldson, of Prestonpans, started off at PL in the school canteen and moved to the role of pupil auxiliary school nurse after eight years.She came to the school in her thirties when her own children were attending PL and is now leaving to help care for her three grandchildren, having celebrated her th, th and th birthdays at Preston Lodge.She ended her  years at the school on the last day of term before Christmas.During her time at the school, Viv went on multiple school trips to the Netherlands, where she went on her first ever rollercoaster she took part in school performances, attended staff weekends away, and helped fundraise as a member of the schoolrsquos fundraising group the Persian Ladies, who have raised thousands of pounds for charity.In , the school united to raise money in honour of Viv during her battle with lung cancer.Vivrsquos Walk of Positivity was held in aid of FACEand Ward : Chemotherapy Outpatients Fund, at the Western General Hospital.The Walk of Positivity continues to take place annually.Viv told the Courier: ldquoPL has been like a second home to me. My own daughters attended PL too and did very well in their education.ldquoThe school has always had the community at the centre of all they do. I feel so privileged to have worked in this incredible establishment.ldquoI have so many fond memories: there are things that pupils have said to me over the years I wonrsquot forget and we have had some funny incidents, like the time I accidentally jabbed myself with an Epipen.ldquoWe went on trips to Holland a couple of times and that is where I went on my first ever rollercoaster ndash and we wrote about it in the school blog.ldquoMy kids replied saying that they didnrsquot believe I went on. Before, I used to just stand and hold the coats.ldquoItrsquos not been a job as such. Itrsquos been a privilege to have the children allow me to give them my time and care.Headteacher Gavin Clark said: ldquoIt is very hard to capture adequately in words what Viv Donaldson means to Preston Lodge High School, or what Preston Lodge High School means to Viv.ldquoVivrsquos commitment to this school and its community has been incredible, and it is strange imagining the school without her around.ldquoHer can-do attitude, positivity and wicked sense of humour have lightened up many days, and [in her last week] Viv was overwhelmed with gts and kindness from across the school.ldquoHer next chapter in le sees her stepping up her role as a much-loved grandmother, but we know that Viv will always be connected to Preston Lodge and will never be a stranger.ldquoGood luck Viv and many, many thanks for everything that you have done for this school over many years of much appreciated service. We will all miss you!

title: long-serving-dunbar-grammar-school-dinner-lady-retires-31-years
story: Sheila Martin, , was born and brought up in Galashiels, moving to Dunbar when she married husband Derek nearly  years ago.Derek, who used to work at Dunbar cement works, sadly passed away from cancer five years ago.The pair had two children: Kevin, , a labourer at a local farm, and Joanne, .Before Dunbar Grammar, Sheila worked nightsht at Torness Power Station.A former colleague provided relief at the school when staff were off sick.Sheila covered for her one day and, after her third time providing relief, stayed at the school ever since.Working at the school for  years, Sheila has witnessed a lot of changes over the years.She said: ldquoThe job has changed quite a bit over the years ndash this place is a lot busier than it used to be.ldquoIt is a lot harder and you donrsquot always have the right amount of staff, someone is always off sick.ldquoThat just puts pressure on and you get a bit grumpy some days when yoursquore short staffed. It can be quite crazy some days, especially when you have a delivery coming in.She added: ldquoWhen I first came, the pupils had their dinner ndash a standard meat and two veg, and a pudding ndash that was it and we used to transport meals out to places like West Barns and Innerwick schools and also used to do meals on wheels in here.ldquoThere was a milk bar and we had to wash the dishes by hand.ldquoThey are going back to main meals now but there is a lot of fast food kids can have too.ldquoWhen I first started, all of the food, including meat and veg, was prepared fresh unlike now, where it is mostly frozen.Her colleague Lorraine Batchelor added: ldquoThe kitchen used to be a lot bigger than it is now it was also all wooden apart from the marble slab for their pastries.ldquoPeople donrsquot realise how much work is involved in being a dinner lady ndash they think itrsquos as simple as coming in and preparing food but therersquos more to it than that.Sheila has plenty of stories from her long career, with many laughs shared between her and her colleagues.Lorraine said: ldquoWersquove had heartache, wersquove had laughs, wersquove had everything as a team.The ladies recalled that during the schoolrsquos refurbishment, one colleague went to take a cover off an electric fly trap and ended up with a face covered in dust.Lorraine added: ldquoWe laughed forever ndash all you could see were her eyes!Another tale involved trying to catch a mouse which Lorraine ended up standing on.Other standout moments included end-of-term parties and the many silly moments and jokes shared with her colleagues.When asked about the pupils, Sheila said: ldquoThey are a good bunch of kids ndash Lorraine and I have quite a good rapport with them.ldquoYou meet them outside in the street when shopping and they stop and say hello. Some kids Irsquove served have went on to have their own kids and I have served them too.ldquoSome students were upset to hear I was leaving ndash you get to know them and what they like. I canrsquot say anything bad about the kids at all.There are a lot of things Sheila ndash who finished at the school at the Christmas holidays ndash is going to miss, including laughs with her colleagues and interaction with the pupils.Claire Slowther, headteacher at Dunbar Grammar School, said: ldquoItrsquos a huge thing to have worked somewhere for so long.ldquoShersquos lovely and so caring with the kids, certainly all the staff in our bistro are, they never see our kids go hungry and always look after the youngsters.ldquoSheila is very much a core member of the team having been here for so long but itrsquos going to be an odd sensation not having her.ldquoWersquore very much going to miss her, shersquos fantastic and such a figure, shersquos just so synonymous and a matriarch of the bistro and the school catering.Lorraine added that although her and the rest of the bistro staff were going to miss Sheila,the canteen ever needed an extra pair of hands, Sheila would be the first person they called.

title: demand-parcels-east-lothian-foodbank-reached-record-high-ahead-christmas
story: East Lothian Foodbank revealed the startling figures last week, with more than  parcels delivered in the run-up to Christmas.The foodbank, based in Tranent, also told the Courier that its annual Jingle Bags appeal resulted in more than  Jingle Bags, containing traditional Christmas fare such as mince pies, Christmas crackers and tinned turkey, being distributed to families in need.Peter Dicker, manager of the foodbank, which provides a minimum of three daysrsquo emergency food to people in crisis, thanked volunteers for their efforts at the charity and those who made every day, many came in multiple times and we are so grateful for your help.ldquoWe were also humbled by the generosity of the East Lothian community as they responded to our Christmas appeal.ldquoWe need to analyse why this year was so busy ndash therersquos no doubt that many families are finding it harder to make ends meet with all the pressures of Christmas and, because we close over the holiday, many referral agents want to help their clients in the run-up to Christmas.Demand for food parcels has almost doubled in the last five years, with staff under intense pressure.Now, Hall, on Tranentrsquos High Street, at .pm.

title: aldi-close-existing-store-haddington-move-gateside
story: Aldi has been based on the townrsquos Whittingehame Drive for  years but staff are to move to the planned Gateside Retail Park, on the townrsquos western edge.The new store, which will be  per cent larger than the existing shop, is part of the retail park planned for Haddington, which will also feature The Food Warehouse ndash which is part of the Iceland brand ndash in one of the five units.Home Bargains and Costa are also thought to be keen to move to the site, where work has yet to start on the development.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of Haddingtonrsquos community council, was disappointed by the closure of the town centre Aldi but not surprised.She said: ldquoI thought that they would not run two stores.ldquoI just feel it is a shame for the Nungate side of the town because a lot of the people could be elderly.ldquoThey might not have a car and I just feel it is a shame for them when they had it on their doorstep.ldquoI donrsquot know what will happen to the shop when they give it up ndash whether they will sell it or not, I donrsquot know.The retail park, which will include three major retail stores, two restaurants ndash including one with a drive-thru ndash and about  parking spaces, was approved last month.It forms part of a sizeable transformation to the western entrance to the town, with hundreds of new houses being built either side of the B.A Starbucks drive-thru, to the east of the retail park, was also approved in recent months, while a petrol station and shop, to the west of the retail park, has also been given the green light.Ward councillor Craig Hoy said: ldquoAldi was a key local leline for many Nungate residents and older people living nearby.ldquoI hope that what comes next continues to serve local needs and does not further challenge High Street retailers.ldquoHaddington is changing fast and it is vital we donrsquot lose the facilities in our town centre that make it distinctive and attract to people living throughout East Lothian.ldquoWith the Gateside development having been given the green light, I will redouble my efforts to ensure I do all I can to stand up for High Street.And he added: ldquoItrsquos vital that those who live here, and those who move here, continue to have access to a sustainable town centre which offers a choice of independent, high-quality retailers. Thatrsquos what I love about our town centre and I will fight hard to preserve it.Currently, the Haddington store employs  members of staff, with that number expected to increase slightly in the new store.Aldi announced at the beginning of the year that it planned to open six new stores across Scotland during  ndashincluding at Haddington.It is also building a pound million storage and chill facility in West Lothian to service its outlets.Nationwide, that will see  new jobs created, although the number of new jobs in Haddington is expected to be minimal, with existing staff moving from Whittingehame Drive.Aldi confirmed to the Courier that it owned the Whittingehame Drive site and that ldquoa purchaser has been identied for it.ldquoHowever, any intended [future] use [of the existing store site] is unknown to Aldi, said a spokesperson.Richard Holloway, Aldirsquos regional managing director for Scotland, said: ldquoThis is an exciting time for Aldi as we plan for the next  years.ldquoOur new state-of-the-art storage and chill facility will be fully operational by the end of April, which will aid our expansion across Scotland while allowing us to increase the range of Scottish products available on our shelves.

title: tims-tales-visiting-nanas-seat
story: JESSICA was struggling. Christmas time had been dficult because it was the first Christmas without her granny, who had died earlier in the year. But now she was back at school and into the routine with her friends.Her parents had hoped this would help, but her sense of loss was still overwhelming for her. Perhaps at her age she didnrsquot understand exactly what was going on inside, but all she knew was that her granny shersquod loved was gone and she missed her.Then one evening during a bedtime story, Jessica started to cry and told her dad that her granny was melting like a snowman. At first he wasnrsquot sure what she meant, but then he understood.Jessicarsquos memory of her granny was fading. This was a second loss for her. The first loss was of her grannyrsquos physical presence, her actual hugs, her voice and care and love, even the smell of her perfume. Now Jessica was losing her memory of all this and she knew it. So she felt that something inside her was melting too, something that had been so much of her was vanishing.And this made Jessica fear that others in her le could disappear and then melt away as well, even her dad or mum. It was a terrying thought and it made her not just sad but scared and insecure inside.Her dad tried to reassure her that he or her mum werenrsquot going to die, but despite being only six years old, Jessica now knew that such promises couldnrsquot be kept forever.ldquoNana didnrsquot want to die either, but she did. And now shersquos melting.The next day at school was another dficult one for Jessica, and home time often didnrsquot make it better because in the past it had usually been her granny whorsquod picked her up.Her dad was waiting for her.ldquoWe are not going straight home today, he told her.ldquoWhere are we going ldquoTo Nanarsquos seat.A cloud suddenly came over Jessica. She didnrsquot say anything and just looked at the ground. This was a seat that overlooked the sea, where her gran had often taken her. They would sit together and look out to the Firth, spotting boats and looking for whales, while eating sweeties.Her dad had realised that Jessica hadnrsquot been there since the death of her grandmother.ldquoOnlyyou want to, he said.Jessica was silent and looked at the ground. Inside, her emotions were spinning. Then she looked up.ldquoI donrsquot want to, it will just make me sad, she said to her dad. So they didnrsquot go.But later that day, Jessica began to talk about Nanarsquos seat. ldquoShe always gave me sweeties and wersquod look for whales and pirates. She told me a story about how a pirate once landed here at Prestonpans, but he didnrsquot leave treasure, he just built the town.ldquoGreat story, said her dad.The next day, Jessica agreed to go to her nanarsquos seat. When they arrived, she hesitated to sit and had a wave of emotion.ldquoI miss Nana, she saidldquoSo do I. Shall we sit on her seat and miss her together.ldquoBut we have to eat sweeties.ldquoJust so happens Irsquove got some in my pocket, said the dad with a smile. His daughter smiled back and sat on the seat. Her dad joined her.ldquoNo, dad, that was Nanarsquos place, you sit this side instead.And so they sat, missing Nana together, being sad together, but also remembering her together.ldquoCan you tell me the story about the pirate  asked the dad.ldquoDonrsquot want to.ldquoOK, maybe next time.The next day, they ed to Nanarsquos seat. This time, Jessica told a bit of the pirate story. The dad remembered it from his childhood and realised that his own grief in losing his mother had closed him down to talking about her. It had felt too painful.He began to sit on lsquoNanarsquos seatrsquo by himself when Jessica was at school, even though he had never done it with his mother when she was alive he had always been lsquotoo busy to watch the sea with her. But his daughterrsquos anecdotes and stories about the seat made it feel like a place of remembrance for him too.The power of stories, to rekindle memory and ease the sense of loss, became very real for both Jessica and her dad. At home, they made a special box with drawings and photos of memories, and things that reminded Jessica of her gran. Theyrsquod take them out and tell stories and share memories. Her dad even began to tell funny stories about his mum from when before Jessica was born, when he was a boy.lsquoNanarsquos boxrsquo was put in a safe place, but where Jessica could take itshe wanted to. As time passed, she opened it less, but it was always in her room. Sometimes she would put things in it, such as shells from the beach, because her granny had loved beautul shells.The loss of a loved one can never be completely moved on from, so there were always going to be times of sadness. But the seat, the box and most of all the stories, stopped Jessicarsquos nana from melting.
