title: cry-kelp-scotlands-green-future-blue
story: The kelp plant, whose floating ribbons we often see wafting at the oceanrsquos edge, is extremely efficient at ldquodrawing down CO from the atmosphere. That is why the survival of kelp forests is so crucial ndash to hit our carbon targets we need to both reduce our emissions and draw down those already out there. Itrsquos also why kelp is as the heart of a growing push towards what is being called the blue economy.Erwes is one of many international and local speakers gathering in Oban on February  for a Scottish Seaweed Industry Association conference titled Kickstarting The Seaweed Economy. He and others will create a conversation over seaweed in a seemingly new language, a lexicon of blue that includes terms like blue economy, blue new deal, blue co-ops, blue carbon and blue biotech.It will be about how Scotland can create jobs in rural communities, manufacture revolutionary products and combat climate change at the same time. In Erwesrsquo view, seaweed is ldquoone of the key elements on Earth ndash we are just approaching the potential of this amazing organism.In Scotland, we have a history with kelp. We have long harvested it and other seaweed for many purposes, burning it to create soda ash, extracting iodine from it, and producing alginates. Though the industry has for many years been dormant, the seaweed harvest and processing once helped sustain communities on the west coast and in the Hebrides and Orkney Islands. And now, in this age of climate emergency, some are looking to it once more as a crop.As he puts it: ldquoWe want to expand the forest so we can have more harvesting. In Scotland, policymakers should consider this. Itrsquos not only the question of the amount of kelp we are going to take, but itrsquos also for the next  years the amount wersquore going to plant and replant.Already, globally, seaweed aquaculture is a huge industry, though % of it is farmed in southeast Asia. Other countries in Europe ndash the Faroes, Iceland, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands, Ireland ndash have a growing industry. But, says Lawrie Stove, managing director of AquaMoor which creates innovative structures for seaweed farms, ldquoScotland is one of the last ones to get going, though we have a superb latent capacity for seaweed farming.A recent report into the potential of seaweed farming commissioned by Argyll and Bute Council stated that ldquothe development of a seaweed cultivation industry would provide important economic growth to the Highlands and Islands.ldquoUntil now, the focus here has been on academic research and therersquos a lot of money available for research but little available for stimulating commercial activity, Stove says. ldquoThatrsquos why we need to focus on the blue economy and bringing blue investors in. Therersquos a desire and a want to farm seaweed, an understanding it should be part of Scotlandrsquos blue economy, and itrsquos coming together.Stove describes this type of seaweed farming, with kelp growing from ropes in the sea, as ldquorestorative aquaculture. ldquoTherersquos an ecological enhancement from farming seaweed in the sea ndash therersquos no fertilisers, no chemicals, no freshwater, no detrimental ecological effects.Not only can seaweed provide a carbon sink, there are also other benefits, he says. ldquoIt can absorb nitrates and it can help towards deacidication of the oceans, by the nutrient uptake that it involves, Stove points out. ldquoAnd it can attenuate wave energy and help protect coastal communities.ldquoBenefits also include the ecological enhancement to any body of water, creating an area that is really good for fish, like a nursery ground, and the creation of valuable jobs in coastal communities.Though this model is called aquaculture, it is little like Scotlandrsquos major aquaculture industry, salmon farming. Fiona Houston, founder of Mara Seaweed, which sells seasonings and salt replacements, describes it as ldquomore like ranching.ldquoItrsquos putting some ropes in the sea and the seaweed grows, she says.Houston is a key force in driving the idea that Scotland needs to rapidly grow a ldquoblue economy. Since she started Mara Seaweed, a product now stocked in Tesco, she has been driven by the idea that Scotland could develop a signicant industry around seaweed.ldquoI spotted that consumers were more interested in where food was coming from, says Houston. ldquoI was also aware that in Asia seaweed is eaten on a daily basis. I thought this is crazy. Wersquove got ,km of coastline in Scotland. Wersquove got a resource that is vastly undervalued. Andwe used it in the past and itrsquos got a role in the modern diet, why arenrsquot we doing it To begin with, Houston wasnrsquot thinking about seaweed as an element in the fight against climate change. That came later when she learned that seaweed was more efficient at capturing carbon than the rainforest.ldquoSeaweed is not only good for you and tastes good, itrsquos good for the planet, she says. ldquoThis is not now about just the value of seaweed as a product. Itrsquos the value it has for carbon capture.ldquoTherersquos a need for the growth of aquaculture beyond the commercial growth. If we could get a bluegreen deal going that would be great.The model Houston and others are advocating is small-scale farming by local communities. One of the things she hopes to do is make Scotland part of an international blue-cooperative of sustainable seaweed farmers being developed by Erwes. ldquoItrsquos about how you create sustainable employment in geographically remote areas ndash and for public policymakers that is a really key issue, she says.Professor Michele Stanley has been researching seaweed cultivation at the Scottish Association for Marine Science , which runs two test farms off the west coast of Scotland. Stanley is involved in ongoing research into the environmental impact of farming. ldquoItrsquos how you manage it, she points out. ldquoItrsquos choosing the right site and size of farm ndash and making sure therersquos enough nutrients in the water to support the growth, and that yoursquore then not going to impact on other organisms around.One of the things she has been doing is looking at how seaweed farming might benefit seale in the area. SAMS is working with a Chinese partner that has already shown that when shellfish are grown with seaweed there is a positive impact on them. ldquoOne of the problems is that the pH of the ocean has been increasing because of the CO dissolving, and that destroys the shells of the shellfish, says Stanley. ldquoIf yoursquore growing it with seaweed, it is taking CO out and putting oxygen in.According to Stanley, there is a fascinating range of possibilities around products from seaweed. ldquoThere are seaweeds that have the potential for anti-inflammatory compounds, antimicrobial compounds. Scotland has a long seaweed history which waned and now yoursquove got renewed interest in it. Among the old journals we have at SAMS from the s therersquos a copy from a meeting which was looking at using parts of seaweed for textile production.One promising product being developed using brown kelp in Scotland is a biopackaging material that could provide a biodegradable alternative to plastic on food packaging. It is, says Dr Charles Bavington, a biochemist and founder of Oban-based start-up Oceanium, ldquoa completely compostable, ocean-safe packaging material.Bavington began this journey into seaweed packaging after he came in contact with Oceanium co-founder Karen Scofield Seal, a business woman who had studied sustainability and, he says, ldquogot really excited about the potential of seaweed for solving a lot of climate problems.They now use the ldquowhole plant from which they make packaging material, food products, an anti-inflammatory called fucoidan, and beta-glucan, a nutraceutical used for cardiovascular health, and water, which will be reused in processing.Oceanium uses only sustainably farmed seaweed. ldquoWe donrsquot take wild harvest, because it wouldnrsquot be sustainable for the kind of volumes wersquore going to need, says Bavington. ldquoBut having large-scale sustainably farmed seaweed is something that isnrsquot available in the Western world.Like many of those working in the field, he is keen that the growth of seaweed farming is approached with care for environmental impact. ldquoWe need to be careful, because there can be unintended consequences of anything, and for what wersquore proposing to work, it has to be at large scale. We need to be really careful and check before we go for huge scale that wersquove considered all the unintended consequences of very large-scale seaweed farming and processing.But some warn that when it comes to kelp, farming it is not where are priorities should be. David Reay, professor of carbon management at the University of Edinburgh, says: ldquoIrsquod be deeply cautious about seaweed lsquofarmingrsquo to tackle climate change ndash we know we have huge so-called lsquoblue carbonrsquo stocks in the seaweed and sediments around Scotland, but these are also vital ecosystems that provide a habitat for myriad species and help to buffer us from the worst impacts of storm surges and rising sea levels.ldquoYes, we need to improve our understanding of these marine systems and the ways in which they gain and lose carbon, but at this stage it should be more about better protecting these precious ecosystems rather than trying to farm them.There is a balance to be struck. Seaweed is Scotlandrsquos forgotten treasure. What counts most that it remains, or even expands as a ldquoblue carbon sink. Kelp clearly matters.

title: snp-msp-backs-supporting-plans-free-period-products
story: Gillian Martin MSP, who previously supported the plans to provide free period products put forward by Labours Monica Lennon, told the Herald on Sunday the need for legislation ldquomay not be as pressing as we once thought it was.It comes after MSPs quizzed Lennon during the local government committee this week on the proposals which would see Scotland become the first country in the world to provide free tampons and sanitary towels universally to women.Concerns were raised about the cost of the plan, which SNP MSPs suggested were inaccurate in Lennons proposals.:University tackles period poverty by postLennon has estimated it would cost around poundm to implement, and has challenged the Governments suggestion that it would cost more than double this amount.During the committee meeting this week, she said she did not know where the governments cost estimates had come from.When askedshe still supported the provision of free period products, Martin said the government has worked with charities and third sector organisations to give products to those in need, and as such a change in the law may not be needed.In , Martin supported proposals by SNP members to introduce an S-card scheme where by women who were unable to afford sanitary products would have a card allowing them free access in places such as GP surgeries and schools.The MSP put her name to a motion which stated "every woman should have access to sanitary products as a right" and called for the consideration of a scheme similar to the C-card scheme used in England to allow people to access free condoms, to be applied to sanitary products.Now, the politician claims that the provision of free products may no longer be needed in legislation, and said: ldquoGetting a Members Bill through parliament isnrsquot easy and having incorrect financial assessments on the cost of delivery can mean that it wonrsquot get government or parliamentary support. I understand that is what has happened in this case.:Hey Girlsrsquo phenomenal success sees it close in on aim of ending period povertyldquoThe fact of the matter is that that since people like myself, Women for Independence and Ms Lennon have been calling for action to address period poverty, the government have made great efforts to work with the third sector to provide period products to anyone who needs them. I see that in action in my constituency.ldquoThis work, coupled with free provision in schools, colleges and universities, as well as many public buildings having free access has largely addressed the issue, so the need for legislation may not be as pressing as we once thought it was.Martins SNP colleague, campaigner Julie Hepburn, said she was still in support of free period product provision, and added: " It is fundamentally about dignity and human rights."We have made some really good progress, but we still have more work to do. We know that the outcome we all want is the same, but we do need to figure out how to get there, and make sure we have a scheme that is going to be the best value for everyone,"Labour MSP Lennon said it would be disappointing should opposition politicians choose to withdraw support for the bill, which is currently at stage one in the parliamentary process.She added: "Across the UK and many other corners of the world, governments and citizens are understanding that access to period products should be a right, not a luxury. We are seeing legal and policy initiatives developing that are making period products more accessible and this will help tackle period poverty and allow period dignity for all."Pupils at primary and secondary schools in England are the latest beneficiary of this and itrsquos a real step change to hear a Tory Minister talk about period equality."Thatrsquos why it would be incredibly disappointingSNP and Tory MSPs in Scotland take the unambiguous and conservative decision to block the Period Products Bill at Stage . If the clear general principles of the Bill are rejected, we will be telling the rest of the world we donrsquot believe that everyone who needs them should have the right to access free period products."The widespread support from organisations and iniduals across Scotland and beyond has convinced me this Bill is necessary and is the right thing to do. Politicians must put our dferences aside and give this Bill a chance to progress through Parliament."

title: Iain Macwhirter  In post-Brexit Britain  Nicola Sturgeon can t keep telling her troops that Indyref2 is round the corner  It isn t
story: Hitherto, Nicola Sturgeon has insisted on going down the conventional route of asking Westminsterrsquos permission first. But now that that permission has been refused, many of her followers will be wondering what shersquos waiting for. Take Boris to court, FFS. Send in the suits.The First Minister now arguably has a plausible Plan B. But she is most unlikely to use it, even though her other options are nil.Boris Johnsonrsquos terse rejection on Tuesday of the First Ministerrsquos request for a legally authorised referendum was hardly unexpected. Once in a generation ... time to end isions ... get on with the day job.There was no hint of concessions on powers for the Scottish Parliament, let alone moving towards a federal constitution ndash something the Prime Minister has talked favourably about in the past.This was the ldquobig flat No to independence that Michael Gove promised during the General Election campaign. Itrsquos a door slammed very publicly in the First Ministerrsquos face.Yet David Mundell, the former Tory Scottish Secretary, had said only last August that the UK Government would ldquohave to listenthe pro-independence parties won a clear majority in . But Boris is not in listening mode. So what happens now Nicola Sturgeon made the usual noises about Scotlandrsquos ldquoright to choose, echoing the rhetoric of s abortion campaigns. She insists, all evidence to the contrary, that a referendum is now ldquoinevitable."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media PymYE poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests PymYE.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Gordon Brown: UK will have to changeScotland is to stayThe Constitution Minister, Mike Russell, huffed and puffed as only he can. Johnson canrsquot stand against the peoplersquos will indefinitely, he averred. But he gave no suggestion of any kind of action, legal or otherwise.This is because his boss, Nicola Sturgeon, is committed to the Section  order. This means recognising that the UK Parliament is sovereign and asking the PM to transfer power to Holyrood to hold a legally binding referendum.This is the only way, she says, to put the result ldquobeyond legal dispute. And more importantly to ensure that the referendum is recognised by other countries, in particular, the EU.Most legal folk, from the prolic law lecturer Andrew Tickell to the constitutional law expert Professor Aileen McHarg ndash both sympathetic to the nationalist cause ndash agree with the First Minister.As McHarg puts it: ldquoThere is no legal shortcut to independence. Tickell says it would be a waste of money mounting hopeless court actions. But now OrsquoNeill has thrown a hand grenade into what was an arcane dispute.Financed by the Forward As One group, this senior advocatersquos considered view is that the Scottish Government already possesses the power to call a consultative referendum. He thinks the matter should be tested in the Court of Session and thinks that judges might issue a ldquodeclarator. The implication is thatthe Scottish Government has a will, it could find a legal way.Now, it may be that the Scottish Parliament has the power, in the abstract, to hold referendums. Holyrood could have binding referendums on all manner of things: smacking, speed limits, hospital charges.Anything that is within the powers of the Scottish Parliament, in fact.But the point is that the constitution is not among the powers of the Scottish Parliament. It can stage a ballot, but what it canrsquot do is force Westminster, ie Boris Johnson, to honour the result of it. At least that is the majority view.:Kevin McKenna: Strategy, not lines in the sand, will set Scotland freeUnder the last Parliament, there might have been a slim chance that the opposition parties could have ganged up to force the PMrsquos hand. They might have passed a Benn Act instructing the Government to honour a Scottish referendum result. But Boris Johnson now has an -seat majority, so therersquos not a cat in hellrsquos chance that Westminster would agree to Scotland seceding from the Union. Which raises the question of what to do next.Alex Neil, the former Scottish minister, says Sturgeon should press ahead anyway. So whatWestminster ignores the referendum result, he says. It would stand as a measure of the Scottish peoplersquos will. ldquoThe political argument would be, he said on BBC radio, ldquowersquove won.It is going to be very dficult for the First Minister to disagree. But that is probably what shersquoll do. Her argument has anyway changed recently. She is not actually arguing for an immediate referendum any more, but for Holyrood to be given the power to call a referendum in future.That is harder for Boris Johnson to reject, but reject it he has. No referendum for now or in the foreseeable future. Do your worst. Itrsquos not going to happen.If Sturgeon takes the OrsquoNeill advice and holds a consultative referendum, the UK Government will reject it as invalid. The non-nationalist parties will advise unionists to boycott it, as unionists did in the  Catalonian referendum. This would fatally undermine its legitimacy.Nationalists might say: a result is a result. Why bother about people who wonrsquot vote  What about the force of democratic opinion  But it is naiumlve to believe that Westminster parties will respond positively to any unauthorised referendum.Earlier this week, Lisa Nandy, one of the leading Labour leadership contenders, told The Andrew Neil Show that the UK should look to Catalonia for lessons on how to beat ldquoisive nationalism.We are assured that Nandy did not mean that riot policy should be used against peaceful demonstrators or that elected Scottish politicians should be locked up. But it was still an astonishing remark.:Alistair Grant: Scotlands endless Indyref Groundhog Day is going nowhere fastPost-Brexit, metropolitan attitudes have hardened markedly against independence and ldquoisive nationalism. Nicola Sturgeon will eventually have to recognise that the Westminster route to independence is barred for the foreseeable future.The precedent of the  Edinburgh Agreement will not necessarily be recognised following Brexit. Britainrsquos departure from the EU has changed the game.In , no-one thought the UK would be leaving the EU. Scotland and England would be remaining in the European Single Market and the Customs Union even after independence. Not any more. There would now be the question of a hard border at Gretna.But more importantly, the Global Britain project would be fatally damagedthe UK were to lose one-third of its landmass, most of its hydrocarbons and all its nuclear weapons. Itrsquos just not gonna happen. We are in a dferent era.The UK state can no longer afford to endorse Scotlandrsquos departure from the Union. Even Labour is now locking the door. This means there is not going to be a legal indyref, possibly for a very long time. Not after , probably not after .Brexit Britain will not let Scotland go, unless there is overwhelming support for independence, which frankly there isnrsquot. Nicola Sturgeon may insist that the will of the people will triumph in the end. That there is no point in holding referendums that donrsquot mean anything.But she canrsquot in all honestly keep telling her troops that indyref is round the corner. It isnrsquot.

title: local-mp-key-cleaning-politics
story: At half-one in the morning of Friday, December , the SNPrsquos Margaret Ferrier paid tribute to her Labour opponent, Ged Killen.ldquoWe disagree on what Scotlands future should be, Ferrier told exhausted activists gathered in an East Kilbride sports hall for the count, ldquobut, on behalf of the constituency, thank you for being our voice for the last two years.Back in  Killen had narrowly wrenched the seat, Rutherglen and Hamilton West, from Ferrier. Earlier, in , as a -year-old rookie politician he had beaten her in a South Lanarkshire council by-election. The pair, therefore, have electoral history.So Ferrierrsquos gesture was appreciated. ldquoI thought it was a nice thing to do, Killen told The Herald on Sunday as he reflected on his loss. ldquoPeople like to see their politicians being magnanimous, they like to see us trying to show where the common ground is especially these days, when much of politics is so isive.Welcome to the too-often-ignored reality of Scottish politics: that despite a mood music of shrill and partisan rhetoric on social and mainstream media, it is mostly local and it is mostly civil.Ferrier and Killen have been working against each other ndash and yet, also, effectively, alongside each other ndash for seven years.They are both from the place they represent and have no plans to go anywhere . And that, election watchers suggest, sets the tone of their contest: eventhey wanted to, there would be no point in running a nasty or bad-faith campaign it would just come back and bite them.This is the case all across Scotland. A detailed analysis carried out by The Herald of the backgrounds of  MPs elected north of the Border shows the vast majority have a strong personal link to their seat.More than half of them ndash  ndash went to secondary school either in their constituency or in a neighbouring one.Killen went to Trinity High in Rutherglen and has stayed in the area since he was a toddler.Ferrier went to Holyrood secondary just across the border in Glasgow. She has lived in the constituency for more than  years.On top of the  locally schooled MPs, another eight were educated in the general region they represent. Four of those had lived in the constituency for more than a decade before they were elected.Another  MPs who had no schooling in or near their constituencies had clocked up more than  years in their seats before they ran for office.They include three MPs born outside Scotland. Belfast native Philippa Whitford, the SNP MP for Central Ayrshire, was a surgeon in the hospital serving the constituency for  years before she was first elected in . Edinburgh Eastrsquos Tommy Sheppard, also originally from Northern Ireland, and Edinburgh North and Leithrsquos Deirdre Brock, who hails from Australia, had lived in the capital since the mid-s.Being schooled in an area ndash or living there for a decade before election ndash is a pretty arbitrary measure of "localness" for a politician.Nine of the  MPs fail this unfair test. That is not to say they can not be local ndash or cannot become local after election.Take Alistair Carmichael, MP for Orkney and Shetland for the best part of two decades. Originally from Islay ndash and therefore aware of island culture ndash he was a prosecutor in the north-east of Scotland went he threw his hat into the ring to be a Liberal Democrat candidate in the constituency in the  general election.:New MPs are twice as likely to have private education than constituentsBut Carmichael was not a complete stranger in a seat where "ferryloupers" can be frowned upon. He had worked at both of Kirkwallrsquos big hotels, the Albert and the Ayre, a decade or so earlier.After  years representing the area ndash and being re-elected five times ndash does it really make sense to suggest he is not local In Decemberrsquos election two of the SNPrsquos stars ndash MEP Alyn Smith and former MP and TV presenter John Nicolson ndash won seats with which they did not have strong connections. Smith took Stirling. Nicolson secured Ochil and South Perthshire ndash despite muddling the seat with his old East Dunbartonshire constituency at a hustings. But this is far from typical. Ochil is unusual, recently, for having relative outsiders as MPs.Local Labour incumbent Gordon Banks in  lost to an outsider, London-born, Edinburgh-raised and Glasgow-based Tasmina Ahmed-Sheikh. She was in turn defeated in  by an English-born-and-raised Tory called Luke Graham . Mr Graham insists he is staying in his Perthshire home after his unseating.Some Scots can take a pretty liberal attitude to what qualies someone to be regarded as compatriot. Politicians, for example, talk about migrants as "new Scots". As a stateless nation, Scotland has no citizenship. That means nationality can be a vague and even disputed concept. Is is determined by place of birth  Parentage  Accent, dialect or language  Schooling  Long-term residence  Cultural or political affinity The same questions apply to what makes a politician ndash or anyone ndash considered as local.Back in Rutherglen, newly elected Ferrier admitted there are those who will never accept her as local, even after decades.Ruglonians, she explained, can be a proud bunch after living in the shadow of Glasgow.She said: ldquoRutherglen is a really interesting constituency because people have really got to live there forever ndash they have got to be born in Cambuslang ndash before you are fully accepted as local. I moved in to the area about  years ago, from the neighbouring ward in Glasgow.ldquoSometimes you do get asked that question: where do you come from ldquoVoters really do believe you are going to care more about the constituency because you live in it yourself and you have some history there.Did it make a dference to her campaign that she was local  Ferrier thinks so. ldquoIt probably did help that Ged was local as well, whereas the other candidates they did not live locally though they were local councillors.Ferrier first took the seat in the great SNP surge of , turning around a , majority for the incumbent Tom Greatrex, then one of New Labourrsquos rising stars. Greatrex, who had replaced a local stalwart Tommy McAvoy in , did live locally ndash but he was originally from Kent and has since left the area.: Gordon Brown: UK will have to changeScotland is to stayFerrer said her local credentials gave her an advantage. After she in turn lost, she stayed put and fought to get her seat back.ldquoWhen I lost the seat in , I was still living in the constituency, she said. ldquoThat actually makes it more dficult for you when you are no longer the MP because people are recognising you and you have to go about constituency in your day-to-day business and there is nowhere to hide, really.ldquoAfter I lost the seat, I had community events to go to in my diary. I made a point of still going to them. That was dficult to do but it was the best thing I could have done. It meant I was facing the public I had supported and represented for the last two years.Margaret Ferrier is not a politician you will often see on your TV or making glib remarks on social media.But there is a very high chance,you live in Rutherglen or Cambuslang or Hamilton, that she has chapped your door, or turned up at a church or community event. SNP activists, moreover, describe her as a leafleting champion.Whenever there is an by-election or a campaign, she is the kind of stalwart who runs a street stand. ldquoI am a hard worker, she said. ldquoI like to talk to as many constituents as I can. And try to convince them to vote for me. That is my politics: putting in the graft.Ferrier admits she is not a big fighter in the national political air war ndash she sees that as less of a priority.ldquoIt is the people in your constituency who vote for you and they want to see you," she said. "They want to see you are investing yourself, to make sure you do your case work diligently. For me, the bit at the end is the publicity. Someone  may say the publicity side is more important.Political insiders believe this kind of electioneering, especially against a local opponent, takes some of the nastiness out of politics.Ferrier agreed. She said debate with Killen was ldquocivil. But she stressed activists still faced abuse. ldquoWe had to report incidents to the local police. It is about how you handle that. I have been on so many doors now I reckon I can handle most situations. However, you have got to consider your activists as well. It is really important to train them properly. It is all about safety.As a Labour councillor and MP who expressed the working-class backlash against his party after the independence referendum, Killen is no stranger to doorstep anger either. It is, he said, now getting better for his party as memories fade of its  Better Together alliance with the Conservatives.So Killen recognises the abuse Ferrier cites. But he also thinks disagreements on fundamental issues ndash such as whether Scotland should remain in the UK ndash can be better curated by local politicians arguing in good faith.ldquoPolitics is becoming more heated, he said. ldquoAll of us, I think need to tackle that and keep things respectful and cordial.However, he believes it is just that bit harder to go negative on somebody you could end up running into again and again.He said: ldquoI donrsquot go in that style of campaigning but I think it would be far easier to attack somebody who was being parachuted in from where.ldquoI just bumped into Clare Haughey, who is a local SNP MSP ndash these are people you do see out and about on the streets.ldquoIt doesnrsquot mean you donrsquot criticise, of course, you do, but we all understand it is not personal. You criticise the policies.ldquoI would not pass Margaret without saying hello to her and she would be the same. We would see each other at dferent community events. When I was the MP, she was at a lot of things.ldquoNo-one likes anyone to be bitter or partisan when it is a community-minded issue. If you are both local, that certainly has an impact.The SNP now occupies space ndash both actual communities and centre-left policies ndash once firmly held by Labour. Nationally, this can look like a brutal conflict over small dferences, and the constitution. Locally, it can mean working together.In two-way Labour-SNP marginals such as Rutherglen, it is hard to compete with somebody with whom you basically agree on many things.ldquoIn a seat like mine the competition was between Labour and the SNP, Killen said. ldquoYou do try and find your voice in there.ldquoI am not one for negative campaigning and I never have been. I just go for what message Irsquom trying to put across rather pick out any flaws in the SNP.ldquoApart from the big constitutional issue ndash which is important and obviously does ide people ndash I donrsquot have any worries about how the SNP would go on most other issues.ldquoBecause policy-wise, Labour and the SNP are very aligned on most things.Killen contrasted this with neighbouring Lanark and Hamilton-East, a three-way marginal where Tories were seen as viable contenders.ldquoThere, he said, ldquo it wasnrsquot going to be Labour I would prefer it to be SNP so it wasnrsquot a Tory and I think a lot of people would feel the same.There is something odd about voter attitudes to politicians, Killen reckoned. The public tend to despise MPs in general but to respect their own local ones. Yet most MPs are local to somewhere.Killed explained. ldquoThere is a disconnect between what the overall view of politicians is ndash that they are in it for themselves ndash and the view of local ones. People will often say the person who represents our area is OK but the rest of them are not.ldquoNine times out of  people stand because they live in the area, they care about it and they want to represent it. One of the other reasons that such a high proportion of MPs are local is because of the way that parties run their selections.ldquoParty members much prefer to select candidates who live in the area. Because they believe that person has a better understanding of what the issues re and would do a better job of representing the area.But does this work  Do local parties get better results because they select local candidates  Killen is not so sure.ldquoI do think although the local thing is important, he said. ldquoI would only want to stand somewhere with which Irsquom familiar, somewhere I live.ldquoBut I do think more and more politics, or at least electoral results, are becoming about the air war. You only have to look at how unorm the swings are.ldquoBeing a good local candidate does have an impact. However, unless you are very, very well know it is not going to decide the result.ldquoI have heard people put the local personal factor at about five percent, which seems to me probably about right.ldquoAs long as I have been in politics it has steadily got more presidential, more about the air war. Yet people still like their MP to be local and to live in the area.

title: indyref2-mandate-claims-dubious-says-sir-john-curtis
story: Curtice, who teaches at the University of Strathclyde, said the election result was an inadequate way of judging support for a second poll.Instead, the professor said, two polls carried out during the election campaign were a better way of quantying public feeling towards the policy.In a blog on his website What Scotland Thinks, Curtice said using the number of seats to claim a mandate does not take into account the effect of the first-past-the-post system, and how it calculates seats from votes.:SNPs Ian Blackford calls Boris Johnson a democracy denier for rejecting independence voteNeither should the SNP claim a mandate based on share of the vote at the December election because voters may not have agreed with the SNP stance on the referendum, but still voted for them regardless, he said.The SNP won  seats in the December vote, an increase of  from their previous tally, leading to senior figures in the party claiming it is time for a second independence referendum.A week later, the First Minister formally asked for the powers to hold a referendum from the Prime Minister, something he rejected this week.However, Curtice claims that two polls conducted during the election campaign present a better picture of attitudes towards another referendum than the General Election.He said: ldquoOne of these polls came from Ipsos Mori, the other from Panelbase. The former asked people whether they supported or opposed holding another independence referendum within the next year. While % said that they supported the idea, as many as % indicated that they were opposed.ldquoPanelbase reported that only % backed the idea of holding a referendum before the next Scottish Parliament election, while as many as % were opposed.:Iain Macwhirter: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntldquoOn the basis of this evidence it is dficult to argue that there is a clear majority support for holding a referendum on the timescale proposed by the Scottish Government.Curtice concluded that the fate of another vote hinges on the public reaction to Brexit, which could push more people into support for another vote ndash as was evident in the wake of the  vote.He added: ldquoDoes it result in a further swing in favour of independence beyond that already in evidence last year such that the polls start to register majority support for the idea on a regular basis  If so, it can be anticipated that a majority for holding another ballot is likely to emerge too.Meanwhile, the SNP claim the ldquomajority of Labour members back Scotlandrsquos right to choose, according to a poll by YouGov for The Times. The survey, conducted between January  and , found that % of Labour members in Scotland said they believed Labour should support another independence referendum, while % said the party should oppose one.Overall, % of members in Britain said the party should support a referendum, while % disagreed.

title: netflix-chief-confirms-interest-deal-harry-meghan
story: Harry and Meghan have walked away from the monarchy and in an unprecedented statement said they willldquono longer formally represent the Queen.The couple will stop carrying out royal duties from the spring,will stop using HRH and will repay the taxpayersrsquo millions spent on their home.:The curse of the House of Windsor: how love has torn apart the royal familyThe move means Harry and Meghan are free to strikelucrative contracts and experts have speculated they could soon follow in the footsteps of their friends Barack and Michelle Obama.The Obamas agreed a production deal with Netflix to make TV and film projects and now Ted Sarandos, Netflixrsquos chief content officer, has said he would be interested in working with the soon-to-be former royals.Speaking at an event in Los Angeles, he told the PA news agency: ldquoWho wouldnrsquot be interested  Yes, sure.Following the Sussexesrsquo bombshell announcement that they would be standing back from royal duties, it was reported Meghan had already signed a voiceover deal with Disney infor a donation to an elephant charity.And last week video emerged of Harry highlighting his wersquos talents to Disney chief executive Robert Igerduring the European premiere of The Lion King in July.:Harry and Meghan will not use HRH titles or get royal funds - palaceHe said: ldquoYou do know she does voiceovers Iger replied: ldquoI did not know that, and the duke went on to say: ldquoYou seem surprised. Shersquos really interested.Harry and Meghan are likely to be highly sought after in whichever field they enter.Former Suits actress Meghanrsquos combination of royalty and Hollywood glamour means she will not be short of offers should she choose to follow the Obamas or the Clintons in writing a memoir, or about topics she is passionate about such as womenrsquos empowerment.For Harry, it has been predicted the lecture circuit would give him a chance to share his experience of travelling the world, while his time in the military means he is no stranger to leading others.

title: stop-marching-start-thinking-insists-former-snp-deputy-leader
story: Mr Sillars spoke out just a week after tens of thousands took to the streets of Glasgow to demand another independence referendum.Speaking to Scotland On Sunday, Mr Sillars claimed it was ldquosheer madness for the SNP to continue demanding a referendum this year.The First Minister has made clear she wants to see another constitutional poll this year, but the Prime Minister earlier this week rejected the Scottish Governmentrsquos request for powers to be devolved to Holyrood, paving the way for another referendum.:Indyref mandate claims lsquodubiousrsquo says Sir John CurtisThe former MP said SNP representatives at Westminster should focus on holding the UK Government to account over the final Brexit deal before touting independence.He said: ldquoWe have hardly moved the numbers in favour of independence.ldquoAnd, until Brexit is done by the end of this year and we know the full details of any trade deal, itrsquos impossible for the independence movement toconstruct a policy inrelation to England, which is our largest market by far.ldquoUntil Brexit is deemed to be done, and we can examine it in detail to see how it works in practice, we cannot devise a policy that will convince people to vote for independence in a substantial majority.He continued: ldquoThe independence movement, and in particular the MPs at Westminster, should stop shouting for an independence referendum this year and instead be submitting the details of thefree trade negotiations to forensic examination.The comments come as former SNP Westminster leader Angus Robertson switched focus to next yearrsquos elections at Holyrood, calling on members of the party to ldquostart canvassing, leafleting and campaigning now to win a majority in the Scottish Parliament.:Iain Macwhirter: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntHe said: ldquoHard as it is to endure given the repeated electoral mandates for an independence referendum, the reality is that the issue of indyref will be decided in the  Scottish Parliament elections. With a majority of pro-independence MSPs, it will be impossible to oppose Scottish democracy.ldquoThat makes the  elections the most important Scottish Parliament vote ever.ldquoPut simply, the challenge toa pro-independence majority of MSPs is the key to Scotlandrsquos future. There are only  weeks until polling day on May  .ldquoThere is no time to waste. We need to start now. We need to start canvassing, leafleting and campaigning now.ldquoSNP members and volunteers, sitting councillors, MSPs, MPs and soon-to-be selected candidates need to drive the campaign in their wards and constituencies to guarantee success.ldquoThere is no time for distractions. Now is the time to keep the eye on the independence prize.

title: lily-allen-laurence-fox-online-spat-bbc-question-time-appearance

title: snp-msp-consultative-referendum-stand-even-unionists-boycott
story: Alex Neil, a former health secretary, wants to hold a new poll without waiting for the UK Governments agreement.The MSP for Airdrie and Shotts also suggested there should be mass demonstrations and civil disobedienceUK ministers refuse to accept it ndash and drew comparisons with colonial India and protests against the USSR.Put to him that there would be nothing pro-independence supporters could do in this situation, he said: "They said that about the Baltic states in terms of the USSR."Of course we all know people pressure ndash remember the people holding hands between Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania "If it comes to that kind of demonstration by the Scottish people to force the issue, then thats what happens. If you look at India ndash India didnt have a referendum. It was things like the salt strike and things like that that forced the hand of the British Government. So we need to force their hand in other ways.":Iain Macwhirter: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntMr Neil made the comments during an interview on the BBCs Politics Scotland.It comes just days after Boris Johnson rejected Nicola Sturgeons demand for a second referendum.The Prime Ministersaid he could not agree ldquoto any request for a transfer of power that would lead to further independence referendums.Ms Sturgeon has repeatedly ruled out holding an unofficial referendum, and refers to s vote as the "gold standard".However Mr Neil wants to hold another referendum without the UK Governments agreement,such a move is declared lawful.He told the BBC:"Its not a Catalonia situation where, according to the Unionists, the Spanish constitution made the Catalonian referendum unconstitutional and they boycotted it."Theres a very big dference between boycotting an unconstitutional, illegal referendum and boycotting a legal referendum."So the point Im making is, lets seea consultative referendum, at the right time, could be legal."He added: "The political reality is,you run a legal, consultative referendum, and the result was in favour of independence, the games a bogey for the Union, because the political reality is ndash thats it.":Alistair Grant: Scotlands endless Indyref Groundhog Day is going nowhere fastAsked about boycotts by Unionists, Mr Neil said the referendum being declared legal would be "a very important distinction, becauseyou decide to abstain in a legal referendum ndash as a third of the people do regularly in general elections, decide to abstain ndash it doesnt change the result".He said: "And the rest of the people who want to vote in a legal referendum, even those who do not want to boycott it but want to vote against independence ndash they cant be held to ransom because the Conservative Party and their cronies are going to abstain."However the MSP said a consensus should be built before the referendum is held, and suggested turnout would also be important.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie immediately dismissed the idea.He told the BBCa consultative referendum would be "dead in the water before it started, because people like me would not support it".

title: ian-murray-rules-independent-scottish-version-labour
story: Currently, the Scottish and UK Labour parties are linked, but Mr Murray claims the party north of the border has the most autonomy of any UK iteration of Labour.His comments come just a few days after Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard told the PA news agency it would be his party which would make the decision on their final position on Scottish independence.:Iain Macwhirter: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntSpeaking on the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show on Sunday, Mr Murray ndash the only Labour MP in Scotland ndash was askedhe believes the party should be responsible for its entire policy position, to which he replied: ldquoAbsolutely no.He added: ldquoWersquore a UK party and I think we have to act as a UK party.ldquoWhat I would do is make sure that the parties have all the autonomy they require.ldquoThe Scottish Labour Party actually has more autonomy than any other part of the UK Labour Party, but it isnrsquot used.ldquoLetrsquos use that autonomy, and that takes away any issues around becoming a separate party.The candidate added that general secretaries of the partyrsquos regional groups need power to make decisions in a bid to ensure last monthrsquos election is not repeated, adding: ldquoNever again should we go into a general election campaign where itrsquos run by London and others around the country are screaming out for resources and targeting.:Alistair Grant: Scotlands endless Indyref Groundhog Day is going nowhere fastldquoWe shouldnrsquot be having seats lost by several hundredwhen there are thousands of activists in seats wersquoll never win.Mr Murray also said Labour would have to ldquore-connect with regions across the UK, including Scotland, to ensure ato power for the party.He said: ldquoOne of the lessons of the  general election, not just in Scotland but across the rest of the UK, is the public didnrsquot see the Labour Party as being credible.ldquoWe have to talk to those communities again, and thatrsquos one of the major planks of my proposal to be deputy leader of the party.

title: ann-fotheringham-bother-bond-tell-stories
story: The woman behind James Bond has entered the prickly debate surrounding whether or not the character can ever be played by a female actor and has made it clear that no, it cannot. Bond is a man, and he will continue to be a man, played by men.ldquoHe can be of any colour, but he is male, Barbara Broccoli, the producer who has been at the helm of the Bond movie franchise for  years, told Variety. ldquoI believe we should be creating new characters for women. Irsquom not particularly interested in taking a male character and having a woman play it. I think women are far more interesting than that.Broccolirsquos comments have sparked delight and disapproval in almost equal measure, but Irsquom with her.Bond is, in the words of M when played by Judi Dench, the first woman to inhabit the role ndash ldquoa sexist, misogynist dinosaur, a relic of the Cold War, whose boorish charm is wasted on me.In , The New Statesmen, reviewing Flemingrsquos Dr No, said Bond summed up ldquothe sadism of a schoolboy bully, the mechanical two-dimensional sex-longings of a frustrated adolescent, and the crude, snob-cravings of a suburban adult.More recent characterisations, such as Daniel Craigrsquos, have dialled down the inappropriateness of his behaviour towards women, but look back at some of the Sean Connery movies and I defy you not to feel queasy.Watching them with my sons, I felt distinctly uncomfortable, and Irsquom sure they were fairly fed up with my horried interjections of lsquoyou know NEVER to treat a woman like that, donrsquot you rsquo every ten minutes.I am not suggesting misogynistic characters should never be seen on film nor am I calling for a ban on Bond ndash thatrsquos never going to happen anyway, the movies make too much money.My issue with  is that he is always portrayed as the hero - in that famous phrase attributed to Raymond Chandler, the man every man wants to be and every woman wants to be with a sexy super-spy who always wins the day ad gets the girl , shaken-not-stirred Martini in hand, dubious and decidedly anti-heroic attitudes towards women firmly swept under the carpet.Rather than spending so much time and energy trying to win this hand-me-down role for women, we should just create better ones, tell our own stories and leave Bond firmly behind.

title: megxit-north-american-press-cover-harry-meghans-decision-step-away
story: ldquoThe Great British Break Off reads the headline of the New York Post in the US, who add Harry and Meghan ldquowill pay back  million dollars in Megxit deal.It was announced on Saturday the Sussexes will repay the taxpayersrsquo millions spent on their Berkshire home, no longer use HRH and stop carrying out royal duties from the spring ndash a result ldquogracefully crafted by the Queen according to the New York Postrsquos celebrity gossip site Page Six.The titlersquos Canadian comment writer Isabel Vincent said the Queen had shown she ldquowasnrsquot going to put up with any more nonsense from the couple who ldquohave behaved like two spoiled brats.:Harry and Meghan will not use HRH titles or get royal funds - palaceShe added that Buckingham Palace did not comment on who would be paying for Harry and Meghanrsquos security while they stay in Canada, writing: ldquoI say let these new commoners pay the tab.Canadian outlet the Globe and Mail said the couplersquos security costs are estimated at pound, annually. It noted comments from the nationrsquos Prime Minister Justin Trudeau this week who said security costs were ldquopart of the reflection that needs to be had and there are discussions going on.By contrast to its New York namesake, the Washington Postrsquos take reads: ldquoThe couple win their freedom from a palace-centric le of duty serving the queen as lsquosenior working royals,rsquo which they found suffocating mdash especially the intense, often harsh media coverage.The New York Timesrsquo Mark Landler also pointed to ldquoa toxic relationship with Britainrsquos tabloids as well as the American links with the ldquounusual deal.ldquoHowever civil, the agreement codies one of the most dramatic ruptures within the British royal family since King Edward VIII abdicated the throne in  to marry an American woman, Wallis Simpson, wrote Mr Landler.:Netflix chief confirms interest in deal with Harry and MeghanHe described Meghan as ldquoa -year-old American actress with a mixed-race background who brought a breath of fresh air into one of the countryrsquos most revered but hidebound institutions.The Wall Street Journal described the decision for Harry and Meghan to cease royal duties as a watershed moment for the royal family ldquowhich has long considered public service its foremost duty.

title: moving-lords-london-option-says-government
story: Conservative Party chairman James Cleverly said the idea was an option being considered by ministers.It has been suggested that the upper house of parliament could be transferred from Westminster to York.Mr Cleverly told Sky News:ldquoWhat we are looking at is a whole range of options about making sure every part of the UK feels properly connected from politics.ldquoWhen the PM stood up the day after the election and said this is going to be the peoplersquos government he meant it. That meant connecting people with government and politics.ldquoThe referendum in  wasnrsquot just about our relationship with the EU, it was about millions of people and their relationship with politics as a whole.When pressed to saythe move would happen, Mr Cleverly said: ldquoWe might. Itrsquos one of a range of things that we are looking into.ldquoBut fundamentally what this is about is about demonstrating that we are going to do things dferently.International Development Secretary Alok Sharma told the BBC: ldquoIrsquom not involved in the detail of it, but actually as a principle, as a principle itrsquos a perfectly good thing that we are connecting government to all parts of the country.ldquoI mean, my own department, wersquove got over , people based in Scotland, East Kilbride.ldquoWersquore investing in that. And I think itrsquos absolutely right thatyou want to be a government of the people, you must reach out to people across the country.

title: glasgows-hope-street-named-polluted-scotland-figures-show-country-stalling-air-quality
story: The countrys major cities, including Glasgow and Edinburgh, have been revealed as having the most heavily polluted streets by campaigners at Friends of Earth Scotland, who have described the state of the countryrsquos air as ldquoshameful.Glasgows Hope Street took the top spot for the most polluted street,recording . microgrammes of Nitrogen Dioxide per cubic metre, breaching the limit of  microgrammes per cubic metre.Nicolson Street and St Johnrsquos Road in Edinburgh, Seagate and Lochee Road in Dundee and Academy Street in Inverness were also revealed as problem spots.:A cry for kelp. Why Scotlands green future could be blueThedata suggeststhe Nitrogen Dioxide limits were breached in all six areas last year.Gavin Thomson, air pollution campaigner at Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: ldquoThese figures are shameful.ldquoThey show that air pollution is failing to improve across Scotland, which means millions of us are at risk of serious health conditions, like asthma, heart attacks, and strokes.ldquoIn many areas, pollution problems appear to be getting worse."Campaigners say the data shows the Scottish Government and councils have been too slow in reducing car traffic in towns and cities.Glasgow City Council said a wide range of work is underway in the city to curb the issue.A spokeswoman said: ldquoThe poundm City Deal Avenues project will transform the urban realm of  major streets in Glasgow city centre to encourage more walking, cycling and economic growth.ldquoSimilar plans for Byres Road will also support a focus on cycling, reduce the availability of car parking and create a better environment.:If Scotland is to be world player fuss over climate summit must end | Catriona StewartldquoSince the start of this year as part of the phased implementation of Glasgows LEZ, at least % of journeys through the city centre will now be made by buses that meet the required emission standard."By the end of , this will rise to % at which time the LEZ will broaden in scope and become applicable to all other vehicle types, including taxis and private cars.ldquoThe recently introduced bus gate on Oswald St is steering hundreds of vehicles away from Hope Street every hour, which will help to reduce emissions in the area.

title: andrew-marr-show-review
story: Best known of the bunch is David Miliband, former Labour Foreign Secretary turned head of the International Rescue Committee, an aid organisation that sounds like it should be headquartered on the Thunderbirdsrsquo Tracy Island instead of  East nd Street.Next is Mark Thompson, director general of the BBC from -, now CEO of The New York Times Company. Thompson was on The Andrew Marr Show yesterday. He was deemed such a VIP the producers showed footage of him arriving at New Broadcasting House in London, an honour usually reserved for visiting Prime Ministers and the like. Not that you would confuse Mr Thompson with a politician: the Starbucks coffee cup marked him out as an easy like Sunday morning meeja type.: Unionist boycott should not invalidate voteMarr began by flattering his former boss. When Thompson arrived at the NYT it was an old fashioned news empire in pretty ropey shape, he said, ldquoa classic case of the inevitable decline of the mainstream media. But Thompson had turned things around, doubling revenue and attracting five million subscribers. How Three things, said Thompson. First, they took on  more journalists to boost content. ldquoIf you can be dferent, and this in a way is the Netflix tactic, pour money into content, make great content, then yoursquoll get customers. Next, more hiring: this time of software engineers. Third, the running of the main print paper was given over to a handful of people.With the Sunday papers full of Harry and Meghan leaving the UK to spend most of their time in North America, Thompson was askedthe couple could expect a quieter time from the media there. ldquoMuch of the American press is much more high-minded than the British press, he said, showing he has not lost the ability, common in BBC director generals, of getting right up the noses of the red tops.Thompson was visiting just as the BBC is living through another period of interesting times. There were murmurings from the Conservatives during the General Election about decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee and forcing the BBC not to scrap free TV licences for the over-s. Now the party has a large majority it is in a position to make its threats real.: Question Time row rumbles onDecriminalising would cost the BBC pound-pound million, Thompson estimated. Something  was going on, he feared. ldquoI worry that decriminalisation is a de facto beginning of the abolition of the licence fee but without the courage to say that, and put it out to the public to say whether or not they want a properly funded BBC or not.As for scrapping free licences for the over-s, Thompson recalled the same idea being put to him by the Coalition Government. ldquoThey came with a drop dead, wersquore going to do this, back in .Thompson walked out of the meeting and got on the train home to Oxford. On the way he started to mentally compose his resignation letter.The phone went: it was Jeremy Hunt, then Culture Secretary, asking him toand continue talking.Years later, when the Conservatives won a majority on their own, the Chancellor behind the first proposal, George Osborne, came calling again. This time he got his way. By then, Thompson was in New York.Back to the present day and talk of the future. The BBC, like all ldquolegacy media had to attract a younger audience, said Thompson. ldquoIf we donrsquot radically change and start thinking about the audience of the future the risk is we age out with a given generation of people and we all are beaten by companies like Netflix.Commercial media in the UK, like in most European countries, was in ldquoreal trouble, said Thompson, with local journalism in danger of disappearing. If you were waiting to hear him tackled on the BBCrsquos part in commercial mediarsquos woes, hard luck.: How local is your MPThompsonrsquos time at the head of the BBC coincided not just with introducing ratings giants such as Strictly Come Dancing and Sherlock, and presiding over successes such as the iPlayer. Under his watch the BBC used public money, the licence fee, to fund a massive expansion into digital, taking readers and advertisers from local papers. Yet there was no reference to this, which was disappointing from Marr, who started out in Scottish papers.Nor was there specic mention of Scotland. Instead, Thompson mused about how the BBC could help the government. ldquoWhen I listen to the new prime minister talking about his plans to really get serious about investing in the Midlands and the north, and to start projecting this countryrsquos talent, ideas, its potential to the entire world, I think of the BBC and Channel  as potentially great allies in that.Doubtless Channel , whose flagship news show, like the Today programme, is being frozen out by Downing Street, will have something to say about that.

The BBC, like all ldquolegacy media had to attract a younger audience, said Thompson. ldquoIf we donrsquot radically change and start thinking about the audience of the future the risk is we age out with a given generation of people and we all are beaten by companies like Netflix.Commercial media in the UK, like in most European countries, was in ldquoreal trouble, said Thompson, with local journalism in danger of disappearing. If you were waiting to hear him tackled on the BBCrsquos part in commercial mediarsquos woes, hard luck.: How local is your MPThompsonrsquos time at the head of the BBC coincided not just with introducing ratings giants such as Strictly Come Dancing and Sherlock, and presiding over successes such as the iPlayer. Under his watch the BBC used public money, the licence fee, to fund a massive expansion into digital, taking readers and advertisers from local papers. Yet there was no reference to this, which was disappointing from Marr, who started out in Scottish papers.Nor was there specic mention of Scotland. Instead, Thompson mused about how the BBC could help the government. ldquoWhen I listen to the new prime minister talking about his plans to really get serious about investing in the Midlands and the north, and to start projecting this countryrsquos talent, ideas, its potential to the entire world, I think of the BBC and Channel  as potentially great allies in that.Doubtless Channel , whose flagship news show, like the Today programme, is being frozen out by Downing Street, will have something to say about that.

title: scotland-political-class-just-like-westminster
story: People have many dferent ideas about what makes MPs out of touch.Examples include: they do not have a prior connection to their local constituency they have limited knowledge or experience of the ldquoreal world because they did not have a ldquoproper job before election or they are not trustworthy, since they are in politics for themselves.Some people think of MPs as a group that, as a whole, does not share the same social background ndash gender, race, class, education, occupation ndash as the general population.Others reserve particular ire for the idea of a subset of highly privileged or ldquoposh ndash and usually male and white ndash MPs who went to private school, then Oxbridge, then only worked in a job relating to politics before becoming elected.These arguments were a feature of devolution debates in the s. Advocates of ldquonew Scottish politics often promised that a new Scottish Parliament would broaden recruitment, notably to increase the proportion of women, but also to become more representative in relation to class, ethnicity, education, and former careers.Such reforms are left to inidual political parties, such as when Labour traditionally led the way in the recruitment of women. There is no institutional provision for ersity. As a result, following a brief honeymoon period after devolution, we have not really seen a major ergence in social backgrounds between MSPs and MPs.Rather, there has been a tendency towards convergence, in which roughly one-third of elected representatives are women and the vast majority have attended university.In some respects, Scotland has lagged behind Westminster, since almost all parliamentary representatives in Scotland are white. The main dferences have to do with the dferent party balance between Westminster and Holyrood.here are fewer privately educated politicians in Scotland, and few are graduates of Oxford and Cambridge, with Glasgow University being the largest source of recruitment. That, however, was true of Scottish MPs before devolution.As to occupation, MPs in Scotland are not remarkably dferent from their counterparts across the rest of the UK. In the post-war decades, Scottish Labour recruited more MPs from the old blue-collar working class occupations and the Conservatives more from aristocrats and landowners than their counterparts in England.Amongst MSPs, this has been reversed, with a common middle class background predominating. Many such occupations ndash such as in law or education ndash were once described as ldquopolitics facilitating because they offered the skills or connections conducive to seeking election.Now, the main focus is on the occupations that may be used as a stepping stone towards elected office, such as MP and party assistants, members of think tanks or interest groups sympathetic to particular parties, and work in public relations or the media, close the political centre. These jobs support potential candidates until they are elected, since candidacy is an increasingly time-consuming task. In many cases, the jobs also help them become elected because they give them essential links to party recruitment. An even smaller pool, from jobs related directly to Westminster or government, may help newly elected MPs achieve rapid promotion within their parties. The proportion of candidates in these jobs, ldquoinstrumental to elected office, are dficult to identy precisely, but we tend to find that somewhere between one-third and one-half of MPs and MSPs have held a job that acts as a source of income and stepping stone to candidacy. Overall, there is a ldquopolitical class in Scotland just as there is a ldquopolitical class in London.It is dficult to come to too many conclusions about how worrying these trends should be, for three main reasons.First, in their book The Good Politician, Nick Clarke and colleagues show that most electors are more interested in more general indicators of MP trustworthiness. They seek ldquohonest, ldquosincere, and ldquogenuine politicians with a grasp of ldquoeveryday le and in touch with ldquoordinary people. A tendency to recruit from the same small proportion of the population seems to undermine the chance that Westminster politicians engage in ldquoordinary le, but it does not undermine their honesty and sincerity.Second, there can be unintended consequences to a too-ambitious shopping list of reforms to the political class. For example, in their article The Politics of Local Presence, Sarah Childs and Philip Cowley suggest thatthe insistence on a local candidate can overshadow attempts to secure more women or people of colour in elected positions.Third, electors want politicians who share their beliefs, and are committed to turning those beliefs into policy. During periods of fierce competition on constitutional and other issues, these beliefs seem to trump shared backgrounds.Electors seem to trust their politiciansthey want the same things, and distrust themthey donrsquot.Michael Keating is Professor of Politics, University of Aberdeen, and Director, Centre on Constitutional Change.l Paul Cairney is Professor of Politics and Public Policy, University of Stirling.

title: communities urged to take the plunge to celebrate year of coasts and waters
story: A new #, fund has been launched to help community groups celebrate Scotland#s Year of Coasts and Waters .Scottish Natural Heritageis marking the year with the launch of ‘Plunge In! The Coasts and Waters Community Fund’, offering a range of grants from small pots for schools and youth groups to awards of up to £,.Applications are now open for community-led ideas that will engage and connect more people with our seas, coasts, lochs, rivers, streams and wetlands, as well as their unique wildle.Projects might include plans for restoring habitats, carrying out surveys or promoting and celebrating theenvironment or wildle, and should leave a legacy from the year, for example through improved skills and knowledge or the creation of a community resource.Smaller grants of up to £ will also be available to allow groups of young people to connect with nature by visiting one of Scotland’s many stunning national or local nature reserves.Francesca Osowska, SNH chief executive, said: “As Scotland’s nature agency, we’re really excited about the Year of Coasts and Waters. “There is so much to celebrate about our coastlines and waterways and we want to encourage and inspire people to explore and enjoy them as much as possible throughout this year and beyond.“We know communities up and down the country will also want to celebrate the year in their own way, but we recognise that some might lack the resources to do so.“This new fund is a fantastic opportunity for groups to get involved, be creative, help their local environment and wildle and improve our coasts and waters.”Applications for Plunge In! The Coasts and Waters Community Fund will be open until February .The fund is a first in a series of celebratory events and projects that SNH will be revealing throughout the Year of Coasts and Waters.The year, led by VisitScotland, will celebrate and promote opportunities to experience and enjoy Scotland’s unrivalled Coasts and Waters, encouraging responsible engagement and participation from the people of Scotland and our visitors.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Kenny Gibb was well known for his work across the Aberdeenshire area"  Tributes paid to stalwart KennyviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Network Rail is working to prevent disruption to the homes of badgers close to railway lines." title: citizens advice has been helping people in scotland since 1939
story: The first Citizens Advice Bureaux were set up  years ago, to help people during World War Two.Issues back then ranged from ration books to evacuations from homes and missing people.There are now  CABs theand breadth of the country, which are overseen by Citizens Advice Scotland .While the issues have evolved over the years, their remit has remained the same: to provide free, independent advice in complete confidence.Derek Mitchell, CAS chief executive officer, said: “We are the biggest independent provider of free advice in Scotland.“Our CABs offer a one-stop shop to help people solve their problems.“Someone can come in about their energy bills but we discover they have an average of seven dferent issues in their lives.“When you’re living on a budget and your washing machine breaks down, you have to make a choice to fix it and send your children to school with clean clothes or to pay your rent.“Making that choice can result in more debt.“That’s when our service really comes into its own.”And there’s little doubt that the advice service works CABs have dealt with , advice issues in the last year and helped more than , Scots.Last year, they secured £ million for the , people who made contact – money which has helped not only those seeking advice, but the communities in which they live.Derek said: “I think our trust rating speaks for itself:  per cent of people who have used our service would recommend us to a friend or relative.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.falkirkherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Hands-on...Superintendent Sharon Comriehas worked for the SSPCA for an incredible  years. A love of animals saw her volunteer from the age of  and shes never left since!"   has worked for the SSPCA for an incredible  years. A love of animals saw her volunteer from the age of  and shes never left since!"
